title: Whitehaven Coal cuts production forecasts due to bushfire smoke, drought
body:
Coal mining giant Whitehaven has been forced to slash its coal production forecasts at its biggest mine due to the impact of the ongoing drought and smoke from bushfires in New South Wales.

Whitehaven, the nation's largest dedicated coal miner, on Thursday slashed its production forecasts at its Maules Creek operation in north-western NSW from a range of 22-3.5 metric tonnes down to 20-22 metric tonnes for the full year. The company said the weather events have added to the company's struggle to find enough skilled workers in the region.

"Production at Maules Creek has also been affected by numerous unscheduled production stoppages during November and December from smoke, dust and haze events which are a function of ongoing severe drought conditions," the company said in a statement.

"With safety a key consideration, this has led to reduced truck speeds in lower visibility environments and in some cases required operations to be temporarily suspended."

Whitehaven shares tumbled more than 9 per cent to a three-year low of $2.73 following the trading update on Thursday.

title: Firefighter injured as crew battles large Darling Downs bushfire
body:
Our coverage of the bushfire crisis is free for all readers. Please consider supporting our journalism with a subscription.

One firefighter has been injured and there are fears properties have been lost to a fast-moving bushfire on Queensland's Darling Downs.

The large fire, near Millmerran west of Toowoomba, sparked evacuations on Wednesday and has blackened almost 1200 hectares.

On Thursday it was continuing to burn in the Western Creek State Forest near Cypress Gardens and Forest Ridge, but the threat has eased.

One firefighter was injured by a falling tree during backburning operations and was treated in hospital.

title: Nattai community told to 'seek shelter'
body:
Residents of Nattai are being told to seek shelter as the out-of-control Green Wattle Creek bushfire is upgraded to emergency level.

The blaze, which has burnt more than 3600ha, has jumped Lake Burragorang and is now threatening the communities of Nattai and Oakdale.

"If you are in the Nattai area, seek shelter as the fire approaches," the Rural Fire Service website says. "Protect yourself from the heat of the fire."

The fire is spreading quickly towards Nattai and Oakdale, with Nattai residents advised to seek shelter.

Waterbombing aircraft is helping firefighters trying to get the upper hand.

Oakdale and Belimbla Park residents are reminded the Neighbourhood Safer Place is now open, located at Oakdale Community Hall on Burragorang Rd.

The communities of Warragamba, Silverdale, Werombi, The Oaks, Lakesland, Thirlmere, Buxton, Balmoral, Bargo or Hill Top are advised to monitor the conditions.

Firefighters, supported by waterbombing aircraft, are working to slow the spread of the fire with operations currently based out of The Oaks Airfield.

Stay up to date on bush fires in your area by checking the NSW RFS website, listening to your local radio station, or by calling the NSW RFS Bush Fire Information Line on 1800 679 737.

title: NSW fires LIVE updates: Bushfire emergencies on Sydney's outskirts amid severe fire danger
body:
Our coverage of the bushfire crisis is free for all readers. Please consider supporting our journalism with a subscription.

As many as 100 Maritime Union of Australia members have stopped work at three terminals in Port Botany because of extended exposure to Sydney's poor air quality, bringing the loading and unloading of ships to a halt.

Workers on docks have been enduring days of pollution levels hovering at or above hazardous levels, Paul Keating, the deputy branch secretary, told the Herald.

"The air is just too poor," Mr Keating said. "And it's not just me saying it, it's the health department."

The three port operators affected are DP World, Hutchison Ports Australia, and Patrick Terminals.

Mr Keating said at least one of the operators had warned it could take action against the union. "To say this is some sort of illegal action is just disgraceful," he said.

10 of the state's 21 Fire Areas, including Sydney, will have total fire bans tomorrow.

The other nine are: Far North Coast, North Coast, Greater Hunter, Illawarra/Shoalhaven, Southern Ranges, Central Ranges, New England, Northern Slopes and North Western.

The fire at Little L Complex in the Yengo National Park is continue to spread to the east, and is expected to reach Yengo Creek Road this afternoon.

"We've now elevated this fire to emergency warning, with the advice to Laguna or Yengo to leave now towards Cessnock," said RFS spokesman Greg Allan.

Cessnock is roughly 40 kilometres to the north-east of Laguna.

The Green Wattle Creek fire has crossed Lake Burragorang and is spreading quickly in an easterly direction towards Nattai and Oakdale. The fire may reach these areas this afternoon, and Nattai residents have been advised to seek shelter as the fire approaches.

Herald photographer Nick Moir is on the ground at Oakdale, where horses are being evacuated from Hazelwood, a property on Ridge Road.

The RFS has just updated its emergency warning for the Gospers Mountain fire, informing residents of Colo Heights and Boree it is now too late to leave and they must seek shelter as the fire approaches.

Residents in the area of Upper Colo who are not prepared should leave now towards Wilberforce. People in the area of Wallabadah who plan to leave are advised to leave early.

Good afternoon and welcome to our live coverage of the bushfires unfolding across NSW today.

The Rural Fire Service has this afternoon issued emergency warnings for two bushfires burning on the outskirts of Sydney - the Gospers Mountain fire in the Hawkesbury, and the Green Wattle Creek fire burning in the Wollondilly area, south-west of Warragamba Dam.

In addition to the two fires burning at emergency warning level, there are currently nine fires across the state burning at "watch and act". At 1.30pm, there were 112 fires burning across NSW, with 56 yet to be contained.

We will be updating you on the progress of these fires throughout the afternoon.

title: Emergency warnings issued for two fires burning in NSW
body: Two emergency warnings have been issued for bushfires burning in the Greater Sydney area. The Gospers Mountain fire, which was started by lightning about a month ago, has been burning in the Wollemi National Park in the Hawksbury region of Sydney. Residents in Colo heights and upper Colo have been told to leave now. The second fire that has been elevated to an emergency level on Thursday is the Green Wattle Creek fire, which is threatening the communities of Nattai and Oakdale. There are currently eight fires burning at a watch and act level across NSW. Image: News Corp Australia

title: Fears fires will merge into huge blaze
body:
An emergency warning is in place for a huge blaze close to Sydney as a torrid day of bushfire danger unfolds.

Strong westerly winds have been fanning the Gospers Mountain fire, a 230,000-hectare blaze on Sydney's northwestern outskirts.

Firefighters are concerned it will merge with the 6000-hectare Three Mile blaze near Wisemans Ferry, AAP has reported.

Unprepared residents in the Colo Heights and Upper Colo areas should leave south towards Wilberforce, the New South Wales Rural Fire Service says.

The service says there are dangerous fire conditions across large parts of the state.

"Today will be a long and challenging day," the RFS said in a statement on Thursday.

"High temperatures and strong winds will make conditions dangerous at many of the 100-plus fires burning across NSW."

Sydney residents have now choked their way through the "longest period" of air pollution on record for the state, authorities have confirmed.

And there is likely to be no let-up from the smoke haze and raining ash until at least the weekend.

Temperatures are soaring up and down Australia's east coast. Sydney could hit 34C today and Brisbane almost 40C as baking hot air is sucked in by westerlies from the interior.

Across the Nullarbor, Perth is also scorching and is looking at highs of 39C.

There are reports homes have been lost in Queensland's Darling Downs.

SYDNEY'S "HORRIFYING" SUN

Sydneysiders have shared hundreds of images of yesterday's eerie sunset, calling the darkened skyline "apocalyptic" and "horrifying".

Yesterday, as thick smoke turned the sky a dark colour and the sun bright red, many took to social media to share photos of the unusual scenes.

"Horrifying today," one social media user wrote of the conditions.

"Hope you can breathe," another said.

As smoke from bushfires in the Blue Mountains continues to waft over Sydney, the particles effect the light coming through from the sun appearing to turn it a deep shade of orange or even red.

There are reports homes have been lost on the Darling Downs close to Toowoomba where fire crews have been unable to beat back a large bushfire, reported the Courier Mail.

Severe fire warnings are in place for the state's southeast.

RELATED: Heatwave conditions hit Queensland, Western Australia

"We're not sure of the number of properties that we've lost," Queensland Fire and Emergency Services Deputy Commissioner John Bolger told the ABC this morning.

Conditions are getting worse and any residents of Forest Ridge and nearby Cypress Gardens who remain have been told to leave immediately or follow their bushfire survival plan as 24 fire crews attempt to control the blaze.

"Fire crews are working to contain the fire, but firefighters may not be able to protect every property. You should not expect a firefighter at your door," the state's Rural Fire Service said on Thursday.

Part of the Gore Highway has been closed between Cypress Gardens and the BP at Captains Mountain since Wednesday evening as the fire rages southwest of Millmerran, a town not far from Toowoomba.

An evacuation centre is now open at the Millmerran Showgrounds. A second significant fire is burning at Carneys Creek near the Queensland and New South Wales border, with people there being told to get ready to leave. Crews are fighting the fire on the ground and from the air.

'LONGEST PERIOD' OF AIR POLLUTION

South of the Tweed, fire danger ratings are "very high" as far south as the mid north coast and then a rung up at "severe" for the remainder of the coast including Sydney.

A total fire ban is in place for much of eastern NSW including populated areas.

Hot and windy conditions could stoke blazes. One hundred fires are burning across NSW, with 44 uncontained.

The appalling air pollution is set to continue with severe bushfire conditions across large chunks of the state.

The department says this season's bushfire emergency has caused "some of the highest air pollution ever seen in NSW".

Pollution levels are monitored by the NSW Department of Planning, Industry and Environment's Air Quality Index. It measures several categories of particles. The one of most concern to public health is PM2.5.

Data and mapping from the department show PM2.5 levels have been above the 200 considered "hazardous" for weeks. In many cases the levels have been recorded above 600 in southern and western Sydney -- where millions of people live.

This morning the AQI for the Central Coast had skyrocketed past 1000.

The Bureau of Meteorology says heavy smoke billowing from bushfires surrounding Sydney will linger in the city basin until Saturday.

Poor air quality has again been forecast for Sydney after hazardous levels of pollution were recorded in the east and southwest of the city on Wednesday. Heavy smoke has been blowing into the city from a large fire near Warragamba Dam near the Blue Mountains, the NSW Rural Fire Service says.

"An overnight temperature inversion will trap the smoke in the Sydney basin. This means smoke will settle in many areas and be very heavy," the RFS said in a statement.

"Smoke is also affecting areas including the north coast, Central Coast, Hawkesbury, Wollondilly, Queanbeyan and Shoalhaven areas."

The NSW environment department says this season's bushfire emergency has caused "some of the highest air pollution ever seen in NSW".

"Recently NSW has experienced elevated levels of pollutants as a result of smoke from the bushfire emergency and dust caused by the severe drought," a spokesman said.

"NSW has experienced other periods of poor air quality that lasted several weeks, including the 1994 Sydney bushfires and the Black Christmas bushfires of December 2001 to January 2002.

"This event, however, is the longest and the most widespread in our records."

title: RAW: Smoke blankets Tascott on the Central Coast
body: Supplied video obtained Thursday, December 5, 2019 of smoke seen from Tascott train station on the Central Coast. Strong westerly winds have been fanning the Gospers Mountain fire, with the possibility it could merge with the 6000-hectare Three Mile blaze near Wisemans Ferry as the Bureau of Meteorology says heavy smoke billowing from the bushfires surrounding Sydney will linger in the city basin until Saturday. (AAP Video/Supplied/Dimitra Harvey) NO ARCHIVING, EDITORIAL USE ONLY

title: 'Leave now': Fireys battle major bushfires near Sydney
body:
The Gospers Mountain bushfire threatening Sydney's north-west and Hawkesbury, and the out of control Green Wattle Creek fire in Sydney's south-west have been upgraded to emergency warnings.

Residents in Colo Heights and Upper Colo are being urged to leave now, as the Gospers Mountain fire is burning more than 232,000 hectares.

The Green Wattle Creek fire has jumped Lake Burragorang at Warragamba Dam and the RFS has advised residents in Nattai and Oakdale to leave now.

The RFS has said today will be "challenging" for firefighters in the Central Coast as the Three Mile bushfire continues to burn out of control.

By 1pm, there were 112 fires burning across NSW, with 56 yet to be contained.

The winds will also leave Sydney covered in smoke for yet another day, as the conditions are likened to smoking 20 cigarettes a day.

On Thursday morning there were 1600 NSW Rural firefighters on the ground battling blazes, with more than 2000 expected to work by the end of the day. Volunteers from Canada who have given up their Christmas holiday to help fight Australia's bushfires have touched down in Sydney today, and are expected to give some much needed support to the Aussie fireys.

Special attention will be given to the Three Mile fire on the Central Coast, Gospers Mountain fire at Hawkesbury and Currowan fire at Shoalhaven on the south coast.

Temperatures are tipped to reach 31 degrees, 34 degrees and 32 degrees in those areas respectively, with high wind gusts pushing the fires east.

"These fires could make a very big run in an easterly direction today," a NSW Rural Fire Service spokesman said.

"We are seeing a severe fire danger in that area with temperatures in the high 30s and wind gusts in the 70kmh in a number of areas.

"We will keep an eye on these fires because they are likely to burn in and around the townships in those areas."

The "longest period" of air pollution on record for NSW is also set to continue.

The Bureau of Meteorology said heavy smoke billowing from bushfires surrounding Sydney would linger in the city basin until Saturday.

Poor air quality has been forecast for Sydney after hazardous levels of pollution were recorded in the east and southwest of the city on Wednesday.

Heavy smoke has been blowing into the city from a large fire near Warragamba Dam near the Blue Mountains, the NSW Rural Fire Service says.

"An overnight temperature inversion will trap the smoke in the Sydney basin. This means smoke will settle in many areas and be very heavy," the RFS said in a statement.

"Smoke is also affecting areas including the north coast, Central Coast, Hawkesbury, Wollondilly, Queanbeyan and Shoalhaven areas."

The NSW environment department says this season's bushfire emergency has caused "some of the highest air pollution ever seen in NSW".

"Recently NSW has experienced elevated levels of pollutants as a result of smoke from the bushfire emergency, and dust caused by the severe drought," a spokesman said.

"NSW has experienced other periods of poor air quality that lasted several weeks, including the 1994 Sydney bushfires and the Black Christmas bushfires of December 2001 to January 2002.

"This event, however, is the longest and the most widespread in our records."

The NSW Rural Fire service has issued widespread total fire bans for Thursday, with hot and windy conditions expected to worsen across the state.

Originally published as 'Leave now': Fireys battle major bushfires near Sydney

title: The deadly bushfire risk from powerlines
body:
MARK MORROW: We've got fire pumps, we've got a dam with thousands and thousands of gallons of water.

We've got bore water, we've got everything.

LIZ HOBDAY, REPORTER: Retired firefighter Mark Morrow is preparing for the fire season ahead.

He lives with his partner Deb near Kinglake in Victoria.

Ten years after Black Saturday the memories of that day are still vivid.

MARK MORROW: When the wind changed, we knew we were in trouble.

DEB MORROW: The whole mountain was on fire. I was in absolute terror. It was terror.

LIZ HOBDAY: The Royal Commission into Black Saturday found the fire that destroyed their home, started when an electrical wire failed and caused arcing.

MARK MORROW: Every time it arced, it spewed out plasma at 5,000 degrees Celsius. So, what's that going to do when it hits the grass below it?

What hope have you got?

LIZ HOBDAY: Of the 173 people who were killed in the Black Saturday fires, 159 died in fires started by powerlines.

DR KEVIN TOLHURST, MELBOURNE UNIVERSITY: 80 per cent of life loss since 1977, has been associated with fire started by powerline.

LIZ HOBDAY: In 2010, the Royal Commission recommended insulating powerlines or putting them underground.

A task force began looking into these options as well as a technology called REFCL - a Rapid Earth Fault Current Limiter.

REFCL works like a big safety switch, rapidly defecting powerline faults and reducing the power flowing through the faulty line.

These tests show how it works.

A powerline hits the ground with no REFCL installed, a fire starts.

Test 158 with the REFCL device installed on the network. There is no fire.

DR TONY MARXSEN, MARXSEN CONSULTING: I have watched hundreds of ignition tests where live conductors have fallen into beds of ultra-dry grass under very hot conditions. And in not one of

those tests, if a REFCL was in service, did a fire start.

So it works.

DR BILL CARMAN, ELECTRICAL RISK CONSULTANT: The REFCL can only manage a number of incidents and even under the best conditions, they can actually fail to operate in certain cases. So we were quite worried.

LIZ HOBDAY: REFCLs aren't the only technology that has been installed on Victoria's power network to reduce bushfire risk.

But some powerline safety experts say, there are big questions about its effectiveness.

DR BILL CARMAN: Even from the start, I was concerned. I could see that it would look like a panacea but I knew that it could not actually control all the risk associated with electrical assets.

LIZ HOBDAY: Here is what happens when REFCL goes wrong.

When the REFCL device shuts off the power on a faulty wire, the voltage can almost double on the other wires, putting stress on the entire network.

This means, they can potentially create secondary faults known as cross country faults, elsewhere on the network.

When you saw that the first time, what did you think?

DR BILL CARMAN: I was expecting to see it, because I was looking for cross country faults. It's something I know about. If you have a cross country fault you are most likely to get a fire start.

Once there is a cross country fault, you actually have a fault at two different locations and so the current is released at both of those locations so there's a -- you could say there is a safety risk.

LIZ HOBDAY: The REFCL manufacturer, Swedish Neutral says the product does not cause other faults on the networks it operates on. Dr Tony Marxsen is the former chairman of the Energy Market

Operator and says these types of faults are rare.

DR TONY MARXSEN: It's not a stress caused by the REFCL. The first REFCL went in two-years-ago and no cross country faults.

So -- they are a fact of life. They are rare. They do happen. If they do happen they pose risk. But it's not necessarily catastrophic risk.

LIZ HOBDAY: As well as serving on the taskforce that was bringing in the REFCLs, Dr Marxsen was also appointed to oversee any objections.

Isn't that a clear conflict of interest?

DR TONY MARXSEN: No, I don't believe so. I gave my advice on those objections and the Government made a decision.

LIZ HOBDAY: REFCLs have never been used anywhere in the world for the purpose of bushfire protection.

The expected cost of Victoria's REFCL program was $150 million.

So far that's blown out to about $650 million.

JOHN BRADLEY, VIC DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT: The package that was delivered, ends up being around 30 to 60 times less expensive, than the alternative ways of achieving that critical protection of the community.

So I think it's money well spent, although we are having some teething problems in the implementation.

LIZ HOBDAY: As the REFCL program was being rolled out across the state in western Victoria, communities were devastated by yet another fire started by a powerline.

JILL PORTER: I run around our house and our farm, so every morning you are reminded of where the fire's been and you look at the regeneration and the moving forward.

LIZ HOBDAY: The St Patrick's Day fires in March 2018, destroyed Jill Porter's farm at the Sisters in western Victoria.

JILL PORTER: Takes a long time to breed a herd of cattle. It also takes a long time to remove the images of those cattle that you see being burnt.

LIZ HOBDAY: The fire started when a power pole on a neighbouring farm collapsed.

Jill Porter says REFCL devices could not have prevented any of the six fires that started that day.

JILL PORTER: I don't think REFCL is the answer. I don't think REFCL will keep us safe.

PAUL FEARON, DIRECTOR ENERGY SAFE VIC: We always understood this was potentially highly prospective technology but was in need of very significant development work. So it was a journey of discovery.

LIZ HOBDAY: Are you confident that REFCLs are safe?

PAUL FEARON: I am very confident that they are safe.

More than that, they represent a very significant improvement in the bushfire safety for this state.

LIZ HOBDAY: The poles and wires companies, Power Core and AusNet Services, both say they have tested REFCLs comprehensively and the devices worked during last week's high fire risk weather.

10 years after Black Saturday, like the rest of regional Victoria, dairy farmer Jill Porter is facing another fire season.

JILL PORTER: You are on edge all the time. As soon as the wind picks up, as soon as the temperature picks up, as soon as the grass dries out. It's fear. And terror. And just anticipation of what are we going to cop.

title: Sue Ashton discusses the impact of bushfires on koalas
body:
LEIGH SALES, PRESENTER: Sue Ashton, everybody is so sad about Lewis the Koala dying. Thank you very much for all the work you are doing up there. His injuries were too much at the end, were they?

SUE ASHTON, PORT MACQUARIE KOALA HOSPITAL: Yes, they were. We knew when he was rescued and came into the Koala Hospital that his burns were extensive and right from the start, we said his prognosis was guarded. We did our very best for him. We gave him a lot of love and a lot of attention but unfortunately it became an animal welfare issue.

We wouldn't keep him alive if his quality of lifelong term, wasn't going to be worth living.

LEIGH SALES: And the woman who rescued him was able to come in and say goodbye?

SUE ASHTON: Yes, Tony Doherty who rescued him in the fire was able to come into the Koala Hospital and said goodbye before we actually euthanased him.

LEIGH SALES: How many koala's are you caring for at the moment as a result of the bushfires?

SUE ASHTON: As a result of the bushfires, we have got 33 koalas in the hospital with varying degrees and severity of burns. Some are quite badly burnt and they're being monitored very carefully in our intensive care units. Some are relatively unscathed and they are in outdoor enclosures and doing quite well.

LEIGH SALES: When will you release them given how much of their habitat has the been destroyed?

SUE ASHTON: Our goal at the Koala Hospital is to always put koala's back to where they came from because they live in populations and in quite distinct areas. These guys, when they have been rescued we monitor exactly where they have come. From they will stay with us for six to nine months until their habitat restores and we will release them back almost exactly in the same tree as they were rescued from.

LEIGH SALES: Can you give some broader context, what is the situation facing koala's generally in Australia at the moment?

SUE ASHTON: We are very concerned about the plight of the koalas and what's going to happen to this lovely iconic Australian. With all over these fires and the number that have been wiped out, hundreds and hundreds, maybe even close to thousands.

It is going to take a long time for these wild animals to recover from that. They breed about every 18 months to two years, if you're lucky. To lose hundreds in just a two-week period you can imagine how long it is going to take to rebuild those populations.

LEIGH SALES: How surprised are you at how much attention Lewis' case has garnered here in Australia and around the world?

SUE ASHTON: Absolutely overwhelmed. We had no idea it would generate so much interest. For the Koala Hospital it has been absolutely wonderful but also for koalas. It has brought them front and centre and they deserve to be. They're just wonderful little creatures.

LEIGH SALES: Has the attention translated into donations and support?

SUE ASHTON: Yes, yes, our GoFundMe account - which we set up to build wildlife water stations and also to establish a wild koala breeding program - which will be the first in the world, went way past our goal which was $25,000.

It's almost $1.75 million. And we had no idea it would reach anything like that.

A lot of donations too have been coming in small amounts like $10 and $20 which shows how widespread the interest is in koalas

LEIGH SALES: Thank you for everything you do and thank you for making time to speak to our viewers tonight.

title: 'It's awful': Open contender says smoke causing eyes to 'burn up'
body:
Former Australian Open champion Matt Jones said his "eyes were burning up" as a result of a thick smoke blanketing Sydney as the world's best amateur upstaged his older rivals during the opening round.

Jones, playing on his home course after winning the tournament at The Australian Golf Club in 2015, finished his first round at four-under and just two behind Japanese junior star Takumi Kanaya.

But the bushfire smoke blanketing Sydney was still a point of contention for the tournament's biggest stars after officials enlisted more medical staff to be on course.

"It's awful," Jones said. "I'm not sure what the forecast is [but it's] not good at all. It's tough to see your golf ball when you're out there playing, where it finishes.

title: Victoria wants to call up ex-military aircraft to fire-fighting force
body:
Our coverage of the bushfire crisis is free for all readers. Please consider supporting our journalism with a subscription.

The Victorian government wants ex-military aircraft to be converted to water bombers as it looks to secure a regular supply of fire-fighting planes and helicopters for longer and more intense bushfire seasons.

Announcing Victoria's "largest ever" fleet of fire-fighting aircraft outside Geelong on Thursday, Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville said the idea of refitting retired Navy, Army or Air Force planes as fire-fighters had been put to the federal government.

Victoria will have 50 aircraft ready to take to the skies this summer, Ms Neville said, with access to another 100 from around Australia, giving the state a "surge capacity" of 150 aircraft.

The Victorian-based fleet includes two large tankers and two aircranes.

title: Weird new selfie trend sweeping Sydney
body:
A strange new selfie trend has emerged, sparked by the Australian bushfire crisis.

Aussies have taken to sharing unusual selfies showing off face masks purchased to protect them from hazardous bushfire smoke.

Pollutant particles from numerous fires around the country have prompted health authorities from different states to issue ongoing warnings to people, urging them to stay indoors, carry any medication they may need with them, and avoid outdoor activities.

Following weeks of darkened skies and warnings from authorities, the NSW Department of Environment today said the recent period of poor air quality has been the "longest and the most widespread" pollution event in the state's record.

Affected Aussies have also been advised to wear face masks to shield them from, with many on social media embracing the protective gear.

Some mask wearers have posted selfies compared themselves to superheroes, and discussed the types of masks that offered the best protection. Others lamented the situation and called the look "apocalyptic".

People "need to put their health over 'fashion first'," protective workwear company Outback Mask founder Nick Avery told news.com.au.

He said the company's P2 dust mask was originally designed for outdoor workers who are affected by high levels of dust, heat and sun, but said anyone who is being exposed to bushfire smoke will benefit from wearing the mask.

According to the NSW RFS, bushfire smoke is hazardous, made up of carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, nitrogen oxides and volatile organic compounds.

Read more: Bushfire fears up and down east coast as heatwaves spread

Mr Avery said people who buy cheaply-made masks from overseas run the risk of not being protected from smaller, harmful particles in bushfire smoke.

"Heavy metals can accumulate over time," he warned. "A P2 mask is designed to filter out particles down to 3 microns."

He said Outback Masks have a flexible design and hi-tech cooling fabric.

A smoke haze continued on Thursday, creating hazardous conditions, and residents are urged to avoid the outdoors.

The haze, which is forecast to continue affecting Sydney until Sunday, has hazardous health effects on children, the elderly, and people with health conditions.

The NSW Environment Department says this season's bushfire emergency has caused "some of the highest air pollution ever seen in NSW".

"Recently NSW has experienced elevated levels of pollutants as a result of smoke from the bushfire emergency, and dust caused by the severe drought," a spokesman said.

"NSW has experienced other periods of poor air quality that lasted several weeks, including the 1994 Sydney bushfires and the Black Christmas bushfires of December 2001 to January 2002.

"This event, however, is the longest and the most widespread in our records."

title: Canadian Firefighters Arrive in Australia to Reinforce Efforts
body: Around 20 firefighters from Canada arrived in Sydney on December 5 to help bolster efforts to battle bushfires in New South Wales. "A warm Aussie welcome to 21 fire management personnel from Canada who have landed in Sydney this morning to support the firefighting effort," the NSW Rurual Fire Service said in a tweet. The temperature was due to reach a top of 34 degrees celcius in Sydney on December 5, in what was very much an 'Australian' welcome. More than 100 bushfires were burning in the state of New South Wales on December 5, with almost 50 yet to be contained. Credit: NSW Rural Fire Service via Storyful

title: Jones' 'eyes burn up' at smoky Aussie Open
body:
Sorry, we can't show this content as your browser does not support iframes.

Sydney's smoky haze continues to dog the Australian Open golf championship, with former winner Matt Jones claiming he'd never endured anything like it.

Jones snared the early clubhouse lead with a first-round four-under-par 67 on Thursday before saying visibility and comfort levels were among the worst he'd endured.

"It's tough to see your golf ball when you're out there playing, where it finishes.

"Your eyes do burn up. I've got that cough like you've got something in your lungs, phlegm in your lungs or whatever, but yeah it's not fun.

"I hope my kids are inside in the hotel room."

With several sporting events cancelled this week as bushfires continue to rage in NSW, children, the elderly and those with heart and lung conditions are most at risk.

Health authorities have advised people to reduce outdoor activities and seek medical advice if they experience difficulties.

Golf Australia boss said Stephen Pitt promised pre-Open to have ample medical staff on site at The Australian, while tournament director Trevor Herden was hoping forecast sea breezes would help clear skies by the weekend.

"Even when I played in China, I didn't think it was like this at all," Jones said.

"Definitely not in Malaysia. It's just unbelievably humid (there).

title: Single post that led to disaster
body:
On April 10, just months after Israel Folau signed a lucrative new multi-season contract with Rugby Australia, he made a decision that would change his life.

By that point in his career, Folau had already caused a stir on social media.

The 30-year-old had grown up as a Mormon but became an active member of an Assemblies of God fellowship in 2011.

It was then that he changed his Twitter profile to say "Living for Jesus Christ #TeamJesus" and began posting increasingly fundamentalist views.

The first sign of trouble was in April 2018 when Folau posted that gay people were destined for hell and tweeted a link to a video opposing same-sex marriage.

Rugby Australia, which has a policy of inclusiveness, reprimanded him after a fierce public backlash.

For a year after that it seemed the telling-off had done the job.

But, on April 10, Folau spectacularly reignited the controversy when he took to Instagram and posted a banner that read: "Drunks, Homosexuals, Adulterers, Liars, Fornicators, Thieves, Atheists, Idolators: Hell Awaits You. Repent! Only Jesus Saves."

The day after, Rugby Australia announced it would terminate Folau's contract, and the following month he was found guilty of breaching the sporting body's code of conduct.

With key Wallabies sponsor Qantas livid and criticism building, Rugby Australia sensationally sacked Folau for breach of contract on May 17.

Standing defiant, Folau launched his legal fight against his disimissal in June and made a GoFundMe page to fund his fees.

This page was shut down later that month, but the Australian Christian Lobby began a new campaign the following day.

Speaking to Alan Jones shortly after, Folau said Rugby Australia offered him money to take his social media post down, a claim the body denied.

With Folau demanding $10 million in compensation, the sportsman and Rugby Australia failed to reach an agreement in a conciliation meeting on June 28.

It was around this time that the Wallabies - who Folau had been one of the star players for -- were gearing up for the Rugby World Cup in Japan.

However, the headlines in the months leading up to the tournament were dominated by Folau and his social media posts.

In Japan, the Wallabies exited in the quarter-finals following a humiliating 40-16 loss to England.

Rugby Australia chief executive Raelene Castle said the storm around Folau was a distraction for the team.

"I certainly don't think it's helpful," she told ABC's Radio National.

"I think when you've got a player who chooses to put their views in front of the views of the team and we end up with headlines and people writing things about Rugby Australia as opposed to writing about the rugby, that's never helpful. Of course it's not."

Folau continued to provoke outrage in the weeks that followed. On November 17 he said the catastrophic bushfires that had ravaged Queensland and NSW were "God's punishment" for Australia allowing same-sex marriage and abortion.

Ten days later he upped his demands from Rugby Australia, asking for $14 million over the termination of his contract.

And now, eight months after he hit send on that infamous Instagram post, Folau and Rugby Australia signed a confidential settlement, estimated to be up to $8 million.

This agreement came after mediation ordered by the Federal Circuit Court had gone for a marathon 12 hours on Monday, then wrapped up over the phone on Wednesday.

With his wife Maria by his side, Folau later published a video statement on his website.

"With today's acknowledgment and apology by Rugby Australia, we have been vindicated and can now move on with our lives to focus on our faith and our family," Folau said on Wednesday.

"We now look forward to the federal government enacting the legislation necessary to further protect and strengthen these rights for all Australians."

title: Coles' $5.25m 'misleading' price hike fine
body:
The leading Australian grocery retailers all lifted the price of milk after backlash from the community over the diminishing returns to farmers, but the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) says only a portion of the funds from Coles' own-brand milk was passed on to farmers.

Of the 10 cents promised to be handed over to Norco Co-operative, according to the ACCC, Coles paid 3 cents and has now committed to pay an additional 7 cents per litre for two-litre and three-litre branded fresh milk.

"We were fully prepared to take Coles to court over what we believe was an egregious breach of the Australian Consumer Law," ACCC chair Rod Sims said. "We believe we had a strong case to allege misleading conduct by Coles."

"Accepting this commitment means that farmers will receive additional payments from Coles, with the majority of the money to be paid to Norco within seven days.

"Court action would also have taken many months if not years, with no guarantee that any money would have been paid to farmers as a result."

Mr Sims said the marketing of the hike led farmers, consumers and the general public to believe the full 10 cents was passed on directly to the industry, but when a 6.5 cents per litre price increase began on April 1, Coles reduced its payments to Norco under the 10 cents per litre retail price hike.

"We are pleased that Norco farmers will now receive additional money, commencing within seven days," the watchdog boss said.

"We take commitments made to us very seriously. The ACCC will be keeping a very close eye on Coles to ensure they follow through on this commitment, and we are not ruling out future litigation if necessary."

In a statement provided to news.com.au, Coles said it disagreed with the ACCC's interpretation of the issue but would pay Norco "to avoid an unnecessary dispute and provide immediate much-needed support" as farmers deal with drought and bushfires.

The supermarket giant had agreed with Norco to lift the price of milk by 6.5 cents in the days leading up to the 10 cent price hike. It says the purpose of the lift was never misleading and the extra funds was intended for the farmers.

As part of the $5.25 million, Coles said it would pay a lump sum of $2.8 million to Norco out of good will and make up the gap to ensure the 10 cent price rise is passed on to the industry.

"Coles is pleased to be able to provide additional support to Australian dairy farmers while we continue to work with industry and government stakeholders to find long-term solutions to ensure the sustainability of the Australian dairy sector," the company spokesperson said.

Norco chief executive Michael Hampson denied there was a dispute about Coles passing on the price hike to the co-operative and said his company had been providing farmers with the extra 10 cents a litre since the rise came into effect.

He told news.com.au the confusion related to what was passed on to the industry was a matter for Coles and the ACCC.

"This is a great outcome for our farmers. They'll be receiving $2.8 million as a lump-sum payment and ongoing price increase of 7 cents a litre on the Coles-branded product, which we will be able to provide to our farmers," he said.

"It will make a meaningful difference in this critical time of need as they battle probably the worst drought that we've seen."

EIGHT-YEAR PRICE WAR ENDS

Coles and Aldi lifted the price of two and three-litre bottles of milk in February, following a similar move by rivals Woolworths the previous month and putting an end to eight-year milk price war between the major supermarkets.

Both Coles and Aldo stressed at the time the price spike was a short-term solution to an issue that demands structural reform, led by the Federal Government.

Coles Group chief executive officer Steven Cain said his company was endeavouring to help make the dairy industry more sustainable, alongside government and industry stakeholders.

"We are moving to provide relief right now," he said at the time.

title: Drought, bushfires hamper Whitehaven's coal production
body:
Drought and smoke from bushfires have hampered production at Whitehaven Coal's best mine on multiple occasions in the past two months, adding to pressures from a long-running shortage of skilled workers.

The multiplicity of challenges has reduced production at Whitehaven's Maules Creek mine, forcing the miner to downgrade coal production guidance for fiscal 2020 by between 7 per cent and 10 per cent.

Whitehaven said there had been "numerous unscheduled production stoppages" at Maules Creek through November and December because of ''smoke, dust and haze events''.

''This has led to reduced truck speeds in lower visibility environments and in some cases required operations to be temporarily suspended,'' said Whitehaven in a statement.

A contributing factor has been the big bushfire has been burning close to Maules Creek at Mount Kaputar national park.

Drought is affecting numerous miners across New South Wales, particularly the base metal miners in the state's west like Glencore, Newcrest, CMOC and Aurelia Metals who are scrambling to secure alternative water supplies amid expectations their high security water entitlements will be cut to zero in coming months.

"We were fully prepared to take Coles to court over what we believe was an egregious breach of the Australian Consumer Law," ACCC chair Rod Sims said. "We believe we had a strong case to allege misleading conduct by Coles."

"Accepting this commitment means that farmers will receive additional payments from Coles, with the majority of the money to be paid to Norco within seven days.

"Court action would also have taken many months if not years, with no guarantee that any money would have been paid to farmers as a result."

Mr Sims said the marketing of the hike led farmers, consumers and the general public to believe the full 10 cents was passed on directly to the industry, but when a 6.5 cents per litre price increase began on April 1, Coles reduced its payments to Norco under the 10 cents per litre retail price hike.

"We are pleased that Norco farmers will now receive additional money, commencing within seven days," the watchdog boss said.

"We take commitments made to us very seriously. The ACCC will be keeping a very close eye on Coles to ensure they follow through on this commitment, and we are not ruling out future litigation if necessary."

In a statement provided to news.com.au, Coles said it disagreed with the ACCC's interpretation of the issue but would pay Norco "to avoid an unnecessary dispute and provide immediate much-needed support" as farmers deal with drought and bushfires.

The supermarket giant had agreed with Norco to lift the price of milk by 6.5 cents in the days leading up to the 10 cent price hike. It says the purpose of the lift was never misleading and the extra funds was intended for the farmers.

As part of the $5.25 million, Coles said it would pay a lump-sum of $2.8 million to Norco out of good will and make up the gap to ensure the 10 cent price rise is passed on to the industry.

"Coles is pleased to be able to provide additional support to Australian dairy farmers while we continue to work with industry and government stakeholders to find long-term solutions to ensure the sustainability of the Australian dairy sector," the company spokesperson said.

Norco chief executive Michael Hampson denied there was a dispute about Coles passing on the price hike to the co-operative and said his company had been providing farmers with the extra 10 cents a litre since the rise came into effect.

He told news.com.au the confusion related to what was passed on to the industry was a matter for Coles and the ACCC.

"This is a great outcome for our farmers. They'll be receiving $2.8 million as a lump-sum payment and ongoing price increase of 7 cents a litre on the Coles-branded product, which we will be able to provide to our farmers," he said.

"It will make a meaningful difference in this critical time of need as they battle probably the worst drought that we've seen."

title: Esperance firey urges focus on radio black spot fix
body:
Esperance firey urges focus on radio black spot fix, water bombing serviceShannon VerhagenKalgoorlie Miner Thursday, 5 December 2019 7:31AM

The brave man who led efforts to fight Esperance's deadly 2015 bushfires has backed recommendations from the State Coroner to fund a new water bomber and radio infrastructure for the region.

Scaddan farmer and volunteer firefighter William Carmody was singled out for praise by State Coroner Sarah Linton on Tuesday in her findings from the inquest into the deaths of Kym Curnow, 45, Thomas Butcher, 31, Julia Kohrs-Lichte, 19, and Anna Winther, 29, during the blaze.

Mr Carmody was on the frontline battling the inferno, and gave evidence at the inquest of the "huge problems" firefighters had with communications.

He yesterday told the Kalgoorlie Miner that new radio repeaters, as recommended by the coroner, were needed at Peak Charles and the east of the district to bridge communications gaps experienced during the desperate fire-fighting effort.

"It would help firefighters in the region to be able to talk to each other and improve safety," Mr Carmody said.

Having a water bomber permanently stationed in Esperance, or available on call, was something Mr Carmody said should also be a priority.

"Water bombing aircraft are an extremely useful tool," he said. "The closest are in Albany and then Bunbury, so it takes a long time to get them over here."

Mr Carmody said a career fire service would not be as effective as other measures recommended, and should not be a priority.

It would help firefighters in the region to be able to talk to each other and improve safety

William Carmody

His comments come after Emergency Services Minister Fran Logan ruled out funding a career firefighter service in Esperance, despite being recommended by the coroner.

Mr Logan yesterday told the Kalgoorlie Miner the State Government was putting more resources into mitigation to help communities throughout WA by trying to reduce bushfire risks.

"Regarding the Coroner's recommendation around a Career Fire and Rescue Service, the Department of Fire and Emergency Services carries out evidence-based analysis to determine the best way to address risk across the State," he said.

"This currently does not support a CFRS station in Esperance. However, there have been more DFES management staff and support brought to the area to assist emergency services volunteers and the Shire of Esperance."

Roe MLA Peter Rundle said that Mr Logan's "knee-jerk" reaction was premature.

"Esperance is very isolated, you've got Albany and Kalgoorlie, and Esperance would be a logical part of the triangle," he said.

"I think it's disappointing that he's ruled it out without that consultation and I'll be talking to the Minister when I get back to Parliament for sure.

There are 16 volunteer brigades and 28 fire appliances in the Esperance region, as well as an emergency support unit which can act as an Incident Control Vehicle.

title: Sydney sun turns 'horrifying'
body:
Sydney residents have now choked their way through the "longest period" of air pollution on record for New South Wales, authorities have confirmed.

And there is likely to be no let-up from the smoke haze and raining ash until at least the weekend.

The confirmation comes as both NSW and Queensland face a possible torrid day of bushfires.

There are reports homes have been lost n Queensland's Darling Downs.

Temperatures are soaring up and down Australia's east coast. Sydney could hit 34C today and Brisbane almost 40C as baking hot air is sucked in by westerlies from the interior.

Sydneysiders have shared hundreds of images of yesterday's eerie sunset, calling the darkened skyline "apocalyptic" and "horrifying".

Yesterday, as thick smoke turned the sky a dark colour and the sun bright red, many took to social media to share photos of the unusual scenes.

"Horrifying today," one social media user wrote of the conditions.

"Hope you can breathe," another said.

As smoke from bushfires in the Blue Mountains continues to waft over Sydney, the particles effect the light coming through from the sun appearing to turn it a deep shade of orange or even red.

There are reports homes have been lost on the Darling Downs close to Toowoomba where fire crews have been unable to beat back a large bushfire, reported the Courier Mail.

Severe fire warnings are in place for the state's southeast.

RELATED: Heatwave conditions hit Queensland, Western Australia

"We're not sure of the number of properties that we've lost," Queensland Fire and Emergency Services Deputy Commissioner John Bolger told the ABC this morning.

Conditions are getting worse and any residents of Forest Ridge and nearby Cypress Gardens who remain have been told to leave immediately or follow their bushfire survival plan as 24 fire crews attempt to control the blaze.

"Fire crews are working to contain the fire, but firefighters may not be able to protect every property. You should not expect a firefighter at your door," the state's Rural Fire Service said on Thursday.

Part of the Gore Highway has been closed between Cypress Gardens and the BP at Captains Mountain since Wednesday evening as the fire rages southwest of Millmerran, a town not far from Toowoomba.

An evacuation centre is now open at the Millmerran Showgrounds. A second significant fire is burning at Carneys Creek near the Queensland and New South Wales border, with people there being told to get ready to leave. Crews are fighting the fire on the ground and from the air.

'LONGEST PERIOD' OF AIR POLLUTION

South of the Tweed, fire danger ratings are "very high" as far south as the mid north coast and then a rung up at "severe" for the remainder of the coast including Sydney.

A total fire ban is in place for much of eastern NSW including populated areas.

Hot and windy conditions could stoke blazes. One hundred fires are burning across NSW, with 44 uncontained.

The appalling air pollution is set to continue with severe bushfire conditions across large chunks of the state.

The department says this season's bushfire emergency has caused "some of the highest air pollution ever seen in NSW".

Pollution levels are monitored by the NSW Department of Planning, Industry and Environment's Air Quality Index. It measures several categories of particles. The one of most concern to public health is PM2.5.

Data and mapping from the department show PM2.5 levels have been above the 200 considered "hazardous" for weeks. In many cases the levels have been recorded above 600 in southern and western Sydney -- where millions of people live.

This morning the AQI for the Central Coast had skyrocketed past 1000.

The Bureau of Meteorology says heavy smoke billowing from bushfires surrounding Sydney will linger in the city basin until Saturday.

Poor air quality has again been forecast for Sydney after hazardous levels of pollution were recorded in the east and southwest of the city on Wednesday. Heavy smoke has been blowing into the city from a large fire near Warragamba Dam near the Blue Mountains, the NSW Rural Fire Service says.

"An overnight temperature inversion will trap the smoke in the Sydney basin. This means smoke will settle in many areas and be very heavy," the RFS said in a statement.

"Smoke is also affecting areas including the north coast, Central Coast, Hawkesbury, Wollondilly, Queanbeyan and Shoalhaven areas."

The NSW environment department says this season's bushfire emergency has caused "some of the highest air pollution ever seen in NSW".

"Recently NSW has experienced elevated levels of pollutants as a result of smoke from the bushfire emergency and dust caused by the severe drought," a spokesman said.

"NSW has experienced other periods of poor air quality that lasted several weeks, including the 1994 Sydney bushfires and the Black Christmas bushfires of December 2001 to January 2002.

"This event, however, is the longest and the most widespread in our records."

title: Bushfire emergencies unfolding on Sydney's outskirts amid severe fire danger
body:
Our coverage of the bushfire crisis is free for all readers. Please consider supporting our journalism with a subscription.

Firefighters are battling two bushfire emergencies unfolding on the outskirts of Sydney on Thursday, with residents in parts of the Hawkesbury and south-west of Warragamba Dam told it's time to evacuate if they aren't staying to defend their homes.

The Green Wattle Creek fire burning in the Wollondilly area, south-west of Warragamba, has crossed Lake Burragorang and is quickly spreading east towards Nattai and Oakdale. Residents in Nattai are advised to seek shelter as the fire approaches.

On the southern flank of the massive 232,000-hectare Gospers Mountain blaze, residents in Colo Heights and Upper Colo are being told to evacuate now towards Wilberforce if they aren't staying to fight the fire, while those in Boree and Wallabadah are advised that leaving early is their safest option.

Greater Sydney is among nine NSW regions subject to total fire bans on Thursday amid fears many more homes could come under threat from multiple bushfires burning under "severe" fire danger conditions.

title: NSW, Qld homes under threat as bushfires rage on
body: Fire crews face worsening conditions on Thursday as hot temperatures and strong winds fuel more than 100 fires currently burning across New South Wales. Five Watch and Act level blazes are currently burning including an out-of-control blaze at Three Mile, north of Sydney, where at least one home has been destroyed. Meanwhile, Queensland is expected to swelter through another day of hot conditions on Thursday. Residents were forced to flee their homes or seek shelter as a bushfire threatened Toowoomba. An evacuation centre was set up at the Millmerran Community Culture Centre and a warning was issued for residents in Cypress Gardens, who were advised to leave immediately. Image: Getty

title: NSW bushfires to make 'very big run' in awful conditions
body:
Soaring temperatures and gusty westerly winds will see fires threatening properties across NSW today.

Westerly winds with gusts of up to 70kmh will push the state's 100 fires, 73 of those out-of-control, towards populated coastal areas.

The winds will also leave Sydney covered in smoke for yet another day, as the conditions are likened to smoking 20 cigarettes a day.

On Thursday morning there were 1600 NSW Rural firefighters on the ground battling blazes, with more than 2000 expected to work by the end of the day.

Special attention will be given to the Three Mile fire on the Central Coast, Gospers Mountain fire at Hawkesbury and Currowan fire at Shoalhaven on the south coast.

Temperatures are tipped to reach 31 degrees, 34 degrees and 32 degrees in those areas respectively, with high wind gusts pushing the fires east.

"These fires could make a very big run in an easterly direction today," a NSW Rural Fire Service spokesman said.

"We are seeing a severe fire danger in that area with temperatures in the high 30s and wind gusts in the 70kmh in a number of areas.

"We will keep an eye on these fires because they are likely to burn in and around the townships in those areas."

The "longest period" of air pollution on record for NSW is also set to continue.

The Bureau of Meteorology said heavy smoke billowing from bushfires surrounding Sydney would linger in the city basin until Saturday.

Poor air quality has been forecast for Sydney after hazardous levels of pollution were recorded in the east and southwest of the city on Wednesday.

Heavy smoke has been blowing into the city from a large fire near Warragamba Dam near the Blue Mountains, the NSW Rural Fire Service says.

"An overnight temperature inversion will trap the smoke in the Sydney basin. This means smoke will settle in many areas and be very heavy," the RFS said in a statement.

"Smoke is also affecting areas including the north coast, Central Coast, Hawkesbury, Wollondilly, Queanbeyan and Shoalhaven areas."

The NSW environment department says this season's bushfire emergency has caused "some of the highest air pollution ever seen in NSW".

"Recently NSW has experienced elevated levels of pollutants as a result of smoke from the bushfire emergency, and dust caused by the severe drought," a spokesman said.

"NSW has experienced other periods of poor air quality that lasted several weeks, including the 1994 Sydney bushfires and the Black Christmas bushfires of December 2001 to January 2002.

"This event, however, is the longest and the most widespread in our records."

The NSW Rural Fire service has issued widespread total fire bans for Thursday, with hot and windy conditions expected to worsen across the state.

title: 'Difficult day' as NSW battles 100 blazes
body:
A total of 100 bush and grass fires are burning across NSW on Thursday morning with 44 uncontained and about 1700 firefighters in the field.

Four fires are at a "watch and act" level including the 53,700-hectare Currowan blaze north of Batemans Bay on the South Coast and the 232,900ha Gospers Mountain fire in the Wollemi National Park.

Warm and windy conditions are forecast throughout the day.

Rural Fire Service NSW commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons said areas of concern included Currowan and a group of fires stretching from the Three Mile blaze near Wisemans Ferry to those near Cessnock and Singleton.

"A lot of a fire, a lot of focus and another very difficult day for firefighters and all those communities being affected by these fires," Mr Fitzsimmons told the Seven Network on Thursday morning.

Hot, dry air coming from the country's centre is blowing across a "devastated drought-affected landscape" and combining with ground fuel which is "ridiculously" highly flammable, Mr Fitzsimmons said.

"Fires are starting particularly easily and they spreading very, very quickly and they're proving to be extremely difficult to contain and bring under control," he said.

Winds averaging up to 50km/h are expected on Thursday along with gusts of up to 80km/h across the ranges, with Friday expected to be worse again.

The RFS has issued widespread total fire bans for Thursday including the greater Sydney, Greater Hunter, Illawarra/Shoalhaven, far South Coast, Monaro Alpine, southern ranges and central ranges fire regions.

The northern slopes and north-western fire regions are also under a total fire ban.

The Bureau of Meteorology says heavy smoke billowing from the bushfires surrounding Sydney will linger in the city basin until Saturday.

Parts of Sydney's east, southwest and northwest were rated as "hazardous" for air pollution on Thursday morning.

Heavy smoke has been blowing into the city from a large fire near Warragamba Dam near the Blue Mountains, the RFS says, as well as additional fires in the Hawkesbury and Wollondilly regions.

"An overnight temperature inversion will trap the smoke in the Sydney basin. This means smoke will settle in many areas and be very heavy," the RFS said in a statement.

"Smoke is also affecting areas including the north coast, Central Coast, Hawkesbury, Wollondilly, Queanbeyan and Shoalhaven areas."

The environment department says this season's bushfire emergency has caused "some of the highest air pollution ever seen in NSW".

"Recently NSW has experienced elevated levels of pollutants as a result of smoke from the bushfire emergency, and dust caused by the severe drought," a spokesman said.

"NSW has experienced other periods of poor air quality that lasted several weeks, including the 1994 Sydney bushfires and the Black Christmas bushfires of December 2001 to January 2002.

"This event, however, is the longest and the most widespread in our records."

title: Fire Crews Battle to Protect Australian Homes from 'Hellish' Currowan Fire
body: Fire crews have been working around the clock to battle the Currowan fire on Australia's south coast, according to the New South Wales Rural Fire Service. The blaze is burning between Batemans Bay and Ulladulla, and at the time of writing was more than 53,700 hectares (about 132,700 acres), according to official reports. This video posted to Facebook by the NSW Rural Fire Service St Georges Basin Brigade late on December 4 shows the brigade working to protect homes south of Ulladulla from the out-of-control bushfire. "Here is a short little video of our crews undertaking property protection on one of the numerous properties that have been saved. It also shows a little bit of what conditions have been like and being faced nearly daily ... 12hr shifts make for a long day," the post said. The Canberra Times reported firefighters were bracing for a "hellish" day battling the blazes, as high winds were forecasted to sweep through the areas, making it more difficult to combat the fires. Credit: NSW Rural Fire Service St Georges Basin Brigade via Storyful

"We are seeing a severe fire danger in that area with temperatures in the high 30s and wind gusts in the 70kmh in a number of areas.

"We will keep an eye on these fires because they are likely to burn in and around the townships in those areas."

The "longest period" of air pollution on record for NSW is also set to continue.

The Bureau of Meteorology said heavy smoke billowing from bushfires surrounding Sydney would linger in the city basin until Saturday.

Poor air quality has been forecast for Sydney after hazardous levels of pollution were recorded in the east and southwest of the city on Wednesday.

Heavy smoke has been blowing into the city from a large fire near Warragamba Dam near the Blue Mountains, the NSW Rural Fire Service says.

"An overnight temperature inversion will trap the smoke in the Sydney basin. This means smoke will settle in many areas and be very heavy," the RFS said in a statement.

"Smoke is also affecting areas including the north coast, Central Coast, Hawkesbury, Wollondilly, Queanbeyan and Shoalhaven areas."

The NSW environment department says this season's bushfire emergency has caused "some of the highest air pollution ever seen in NSW".

"Recently NSW has experienced elevated levels of pollutants as a result of smoke from the bushfire emergency, and dust caused by the severe drought," a spokesman said.

"NSW has experienced other periods of poor air quality that lasted several weeks, including the 1994 Sydney bushfires and the Black Christmas bushfires of December 2001 to January 2002.

"This event, however, is the longest and the most widespread in our records."

The NSW Rural Fire service has issued widespread total fire bans for Thursday, with hot and windy conditions expected to worsen across the state.

title: Fears two buildings lost as bushfire rages south-west of Toowoomba
body:
Our coverage of the bushfire crisis is free for all readers. Please consider supporting our journalism with a subscription.

Evacuated residents have spent the night in temporary accommodation as an out-of-control bushfire continues to threaten their communities within the Toowoomba region.

There are unconfirmed reports overnight two buildings have been destroyed by the blaze at Millmerran, about 75 kilometres south-west of Toowoomba.

A Queensland Fire and Emergency Service spokeswoman said there were 46 bushfires across the state on Thursday and only one urgent evacuation order remained in place - urging residents in Cypress Gardens and Forest Ridge in the path of the Millmerran fire to flee their homes.

QFES Assistant Commissioner John Bolger told ABC Radio Brisbane on Thursday firefighters believed two structures had been consumed by the Millmerran bushfire, but fire crews had not been able to confirm these reports and they were not sure whether houses or sheds were involved.

title: NSW bushfires to make 'very big run' in awful conditions
body:
Soaring temperatures and gusty westerly winds will see fires threatening properties across NSW today.

Westerly winds with gusts of up to 70kmh will push the state's 100 fires, 73 of those out-of-control, towards populated coastal areas.

The winds will also leave Sydney covered in smoke for yet another day, as the conditions are likened to smoking 20 cigarettes a day.

On Thursday morning there were 1600 NSW Rural firefighters on the ground battling blazes, with more than 2000 expected to work by the end of the day.

Special attention will be given to the Three Mile fire on the Central Coast, Gospers Mountain fire at Hawkesbury and Currowan fire at Shoalhaven on the south coast.

Temperatures are tipped to reach 31 degrees, 34 degrees and 32 degrees in those areas respectively, with high wind gusts pushing the fires east.

"These fires could make a very big run in an easterly direction today," a NSW Rural Fire Service spokesman said.

"We are seeing a severe fire danger in that area with temperatures in the high 30s and wind gusts in the 70kmh in a number of areas.

"We will keep an eye on these fires because they are likely to burn in and around the townships in those areas."

The "longest period" of air pollution on record for NSW is also set to continue.

The Bureau of Meteorology said heavy smoke billowing from bushfires surrounding Sydney would linger in the city basin until Saturday.

Poor air quality has been forecast for Sydney after hazardous levels of pollution were recorded in the east and southwest of the city on Wednesday.

Heavy smoke has been blowing into the city from a large fire near Warragamba Dam near the Blue Mountains, the NSW Rural Fire Service says.

"An overnight temperature inversion will trap the smoke in the Sydney basin. This means smoke will settle in many areas and be very heavy," the RFS said in a statement.

"Smoke is also affecting areas including the north coast, Central Coast, Hawkesbury, Wollondilly, Queanbeyan and Shoalhaven areas."

The NSW environment department says this season's bushfire emergency has caused "some of the highest air pollution ever seen in NSW".

"Recently NSW has experienced elevated levels of pollutants as a result of smoke from the bushfire emergency, and dust caused by the severe drought," a spokesman said.

"NSW has experienced other periods of poor air quality that lasted several weeks, including the 1994 Sydney bushfires and the Black Christmas bushfires of December 2001 to January 2002.

"This event, however, is the longest and the most widespread in our records."

Originally published as NSW bushfires to make 'very big run' in awful conditions

title: NSW endures longest spell of air pollution on record as bushfires menace Queensland
body:
Queenslanders have been warned to expect a tough bushfire day on Thursday as Sydney and large parts of New South Wales continue to struggle with "the longest and the most widespread" period on record of poor air quality and hazardous levels of pollution.

Queensland fire crews failed to beat back a large bushfire threatening lives and homes near Toowoomba on Wednesday night.

The state's Rural Fire Service said on Thursday conditions were getting worse and any residents of Forest Ridge and nearby Cypress Gardens should leave immediately or follow their bushfire survival plan, as 24 fire crews tried to control the blaze.

"Fire crews are working to contain the fire but firefighters may not be able to protect every property," the RFS said. "You should not expect a firefighter at your door."

Part of the Gore Highway has been closed between Cypress Gardens and Captains Mountain since Wednesday evening as the fire raged south-west of Millmerran, outside Toowoomba. An evacuation centre was opened at the Millmerran showgrounds.

A second significant fire was burning at Carneys Creek near the NSW border, with people there being told to get ready to leave. Crews were fighting the fire on the ground and from the air.

Temperatures in many parts of Queensland were forecast to soar on Thursday, with Brisbane expecting 36C and Ipswich as high as 39C.

The south-east of the state was blanketed in smoke in many parts, as Sydney and large parts of NSW faced the "longest period" of air pollution on record.

The Bureau of Meteorology said heavy smoke billowing from bushfires surrounding Sydney would linger in the city basin until Saturday.

Hazardous levels of pollution were recorded in the east and south-west of Sydney on Wednesday. Heavy smoke has been blowing into the city from a large fire near Warragamba Dam near the Blue Mountains, the NSW Rural Fire Service said.

"An overnight temperature inversion will trap the smoke in the Sydney basin. This means smoke will settle in many areas and be very heavy," the RFS said on Thursday.

"Smoke is also affecting areas including the north coast, central coast, Hawkesbury, Wollondilly, Queanbeyan and Shoalhaven areas."

The NSW environment department said this season's bushfire emergency had caused "some of the highest air pollution ever seen in NSW".

"NSW has experienced elevated levels of pollutants as a result of smoke from the bushfire emergency, and dust caused by the severe drought," a spokesman said.

"NSW has experienced other periods of poor air quality that lasted several weeks, including the 1994 Sydney bushfires and the Black Christmas bushfires of December 2001 to January 2002.

"This event, however, is the longest and the most widespread in our records."

The Rural Fire Service issued widespread total fire bans for Thursday, with hot and windy conditions expected to worsen across the state.

title: 'Leave now' notice for Darling Downs blaze
body:
FIRE crews have been unable to beat back a large bushfire that is threatening lives and homes in the state's southeast corner near Toowoomba.

Conditions are getting worse and any residents of Forest Ridge and nearby Cypress Gardens who remain have again this morning been told to leave immediately or follow their bushfire survival plan as 24 fire crews attempt to control the blaze.

"Fire crews are working to contain the fire but firefighters may not be able to protect every property. You should not expect a firefighter at your door," the state's Rural Fire Service said this morning.

Part of the Gore Highway has been closed between Cypress Gardens and the BP at Captains Mountain since last night as the fire rages southwest of Millmerran, a town not far from Toowoomba.

An evacuation centre is now open at the Millmerran Showgrounds.

Cypress Gardens local Douglas Grist, who said he believed homes may have been lost to the blaze, fled to the community centre with his dog, Shadow.

" ... I was really worried about my property," Douglas Grist told The Courier-Mail yesterday.

A second fire significant fire is burning at Carneys Creek near the Queensland and New South Wales Border, with people there being told to get ready to leave.

Crews are fighting the fire on the ground and from the air.

"My house was probably about one kilometre away from the fire (but) I went to check at about 6.30pm and the winds must have changed because it was safe."

Bureau of Meteorology Senior Meteorologist Johnty Hall said conditions in the coming days probably were unlikely to provide any relief as hot and dry conditions were to continue.
