title: Backup power ready as grid braces for heat
body:
Extreme temperatures will put coal-fired power plants under stress this summer, but backup electricity sources should be able to prevent any blackouts.

The Australian Energy Market Operator on Wednesday released its summer readiness plan as the electricity system braces for high temperatures and possible outages caused by bushfires.

Most of the backup power has been sourced for Victoria and South Australia, with the rest in New South Wales and Queensland.

AEMO chief executive Audrey Zibelman said unexpected events could and did happen, so it was pivotal emergency resources were available.

"The Bureau of Meteorology is forecasting both warmer than average and extreme temperatures this summer, and an ongoing and significant risk of bushfires with drier than usual conditions," she said.

"These risks add to the deteriorating reliability of some of the older coal generation plants."

Rooftop and grid-scale solar power have made up the majority of new generation in the National Electricity Market since last summer, AEMO says.

"The introduction of these resources delivers a welcomed improvement to reliability and reduces the need to procure further out of market reserves," Ms Zibelman said.

Most of the backup power sources will only be paid for if they're needed, she added.

AEMO doesn't expect drought conditions to make much of a dent in power supply.

Federal Energy Minister Angus Taylor says the increased risks pointed out by AEMO is why he's focused on a reliability plan.

"The plan tasked the Energy Security Board to review the reliability standard which will ensure that there is affordable and reliable energy for Australian business and households into the future," he told AAP.

title: NSW Now: Bushfires destroy homes overnight, poor air quality sees a rise in medical demand
body:
The Rural Fire Service has issued very high fire danger rating for Sydney and the Illawarra as around 100 bush fires continue to burn state-wide.

A bushfire burning in Currowan, north of Batemans Bay, continues to move east towards Bawley Point and has resulted in the loss of structures in Termeil overnight.

Another fire destroyed a home and damaged two others in Kilaben Bay, Lake Macquarie last night, despite the efforts of 30 firefighters and 12 trucks.

A total fire ban is in place across The Greater Hunter, Northern Slopes and North Western areas due to very high fire danger across the east coast and the north coast towards the Queensland border.

Authorities say the smoke haze across much of New South Wales is damaging the health of residents.

The Air Quality Index across Sydney and parts of the mid north coast has exceeded hazardous levels again today, with Liverpool and surrounding areas in Sydney's south-west the worst hit.

NSW Health said bushfires were to blame for an increase in people presenting to emergency departments with asthma and breathing difficulties.

Doctor Richard Broome described a 10 per cent increase in paramedic calls and a 10 per cent increase in Emergency Department presentations in recent weeks.

A new global study involving 600,000 students from 79 countries has found Australian students are continuing to slide in maths, reading and science.

The most alarming fall was in maths, where for the first time students from NSW had fallen below the OECD average.

Janine Sprakel, who runs the schools program at the Australian Mathematical Sciences Institute, said a lack of qualified teachers was a big part of the problem.

"The further you go from capital cities, the less likely you are to encounter a teacher who has a maths degree," she said.

A 38-year-old man will appear in court today following a police investigation into the alleged online grooming of a Sydney teenager.

Police said the man from Sydney's north-west believed he was speaking with a 14-year-old girl this year but was talking to officers from the sex crimes squad.

Police allege he engaged in conversations about sexually explicit acts and sent sexually explicit material.

He was arrested in October and was remanded in custody to appear in Blacktown Local Court today.

Inner West Liberal councillor Julie Passas has proposed mandatory drug and alcohol testing of all councillors prior to meetings.

Cr Passas submitted the notice of motion but it has been deferred to allow for further information to be reported to council.

Independent councillor Pauline Lockie argued the testing would cost $24,000 per year.

Kiama Council on the NSW south coast recently implemented a similar policy, according to the Office of Local Government.

Damage from last week's flash storm resulted in the largest power outage in recent years, the electricity supplier says.

Power has been restored to all 52,000 homes and businesses who experienced a black out after last Tuesday's wild weather, with the last 100 being connected overnight in Pymble and Killara -- a week on from the storm.

More than 700 workers rebuilt the network, including reinforcements from outside Sydney, restoring power to schools, hospitals and other essential services.

title: Minister quashes Esperance career fire service call
body:
Minister quashes career fire service call for Esperance in wake of coronial inquestJason Mennell and Tom ZaunmayrKalgoorlie Miner Wednesday, 4 December 2019 7:15AM

An inquest into the devastating 2015 Esperance bushfires that killed four people and ravaged vast tracts of farmland has called on the State Government to urgently ramp up resources in the State's south-east.

The coronial inquest into the deaths of Kym Curnow, Thomas Butcher, Julia Kohrs-Lichte and Anna Winther was yesterday released with 12 recommendations.

They included establishing a career fire and rescue service station in Esperance and funding a water bomber to be stationed in the Wheatbelt during fire season.

Emergency Services Minister Fran Logan immediately ruled out establishment of a career fire service.

Mr Logan said the State was instead putting "unprecedented investment" into bushfire mitigation as well as providing financial support for local governments to identify and treat their own bushfire risks.

Subscribers can access the detailed response from the coroner here, and read full responses from those mentioned in this story in today's Kalgoorlie Miner.

Roe MLA Peter Rundle said the State should ensure a career fire and rescue station be operational by next summer.

The Coroner's findings detail the futile situation facing first responders, led by Scaddan farmer and volunteer firefighter William Carmody, as they watched the fires evolve into the monster which would claim four lives.

By noon on November 17, Mr Carmody witnessed from the air evidence the Cascades fire had jumped a 250m salt lake, leading to the bleak realisation that "nothing on Earth is going to stop this".

"I hope their work is not in vain and the State Government gives due regard to what the people who actually fight these fires say they need to save lives in the future when the next bushfire inevitably rages in Esperance," coroner Sarah Linton said.

Shire of Esperance president Ian Mickel yesterday told the Kalgoorlie Miner mitigation was work was essential.

title: Fire danger downgraded for parts of NSW
body:
Firefighters battling bushfires surrounding Sydney face another day of tough conditions as a smoke haze continues to shroud Sydney and diminish air quality.

Warm, dry and windy weather is forecast for the state on Wednesday and total fire bans in place for the greater Hunter, the north western and northern slopes regions in the northeast of NSW.

The fire danger is rated at very high along most of the NSW coast as and high in the far south coast and Monaro alpine areas,

"Windy and generally dry conditions will result in elevated fire dangers across parts of NSW," the Bureau of Meteorology said.

The state government has again warned the air quality will again be "poor" or "hazardous" across most of Sydney, with thick smoke settling in the city basin.

Lingering smoke could be "unhealthy for sensitive people, and could cause symptoms, especially in people with heart or lung disease", the state's environment department said.

Air quality was "hazardous" in Sydney's east and southwest on Tuesday but "good" in the northwest.

The smoke is coming from large bushfires in the Blue Mountains and others near Warragamba Dam, and in the Hawkesbury area.

There were some 111 fires burning across NSW on Tuesday evening, with 54 of these uncontained.

However, the Currowan blaze near Batemans Bay has been downgraded on Wednesday to 'watch and act' level after at least one home near Kioloa was destroyed on Tuesday.

"Fire conditions have started to ease across parts of the fireground," the NSW Rural Fire Service said.

Damage assessment teams investigating the impact of the Currowan fire, which is still not fully under control, are expected to try to go in again on Wednesday.

The Currowan fire has burnt through more than 47,000 hectares.

Meanwhile, most other fires around Sydney have been downgraded to 'advice' level, although a bushfire that was burning on Sydney's western outskirts on Tuesday night is still at 'watch and act'.

The 5600-hectare Three Mile fire is burning in the Yengo and Dharug national parks.

title: Backup power ready as grid braces for heat
body:
Extreme temperatures will put coal-fired power plants under stress this summer, but backup electricity sources should be able to prevent any blackouts.

The Australian Energy Market Operator on Wednesday released its summer readiness plan as the electricity system braces for high temperatures and possible outages caused by bushfires.

"The Bureau of Meteorology is forecasting both warmer than average and extreme temperatures this summer, and an ongoing and significant risk of bushfires with drier than usual conditions," she said.

"These risks add to the deteriorating reliability of some of the older coal generation plants."

Rooftop and grid-scale solar power have made up the majority of new generation in the National Electricity Market since last summer, AEMO says.

"The introduction of these resources delivers a welcomed improvement to reliability and reduces the need to procure further out of market reserves," Ms Zibelman said.

Most of the backup power sources will only be paid for if they're needed, she added.

AEMO doesn't expect drought conditions to make much of a dent in power supply.

Federal Energy Minister Angus Taylor says the increased risks pointed out by AEMO is why he's focused on a reliability plan.

"The plan tasked the Energy Security Board to review the reliability standard which will ensure that there is affordable and reliable energy for Australian business and households into the future," he told AAP.

title: Fire risk closes Forrestdale school
body:
Classes at a primary school in Perth's south have been cancelled as authorities continue to monitor a bushfire that threatened lives and homes yesterday.

The Department of Fire and Emergency Services said the blaze in Forrestdale is now contained and under control after burning 47 hectares.

Forrestdale Primary School will be closed today. Any parents unable to make arrangements to keep their children home can send them to Neerigen Brook Primary School.

A DFES spokesperson said up to 90 firefighters were at the scene overnight actively fighting the fire.

A bushfire advice remains in place for people in an area bounded by Nicholson Road, Armadale Road, Oxley Road and Tonkin Highway.

There is no threat to lives and homes but the fire is causing a lot of smoke.

A temporary evacuation centre remains open at the Armadale Arena, 4 Townley Street Armadale. Pets, except guide and assistance dogs, are prohibited.

Perth sweltered through it's earliest 40 degree December day on record yesterday and the fire risk is expected to remain high for the rest of the week.

Today's maximum is forecast to be 36 degrees Celsius while tomorrow it is 38.

title: Sydney air as bad as smoking 34 ciggies
body:
Bushfires surrounding Sydney will again pollute parts of the city today, following on from another day of "poor" air quality yesterday.

The most highly polluted areas of Sydney, in the southwest, registered 680 PM2.5. yesterday, according to NSW Department of Environment data.

According to an app that compares pollution with smoking, that reading was the equivalent of 34 cigarettes if someone breathed in the air all day.

The Daily Telegraph has crunched the numbers for other parts of the state - showing that breathing air outside all day in the city's east yesterday was similar to smoking 19 cigarettes, while Port Macquarie hit 17 ciggies a day and Lismore 20.

Today, firefighters are facing tough conditions while they battle fires around the state.

Warm, dry and windy weather is forecast for the state today, with total fire bans in place for the greater Hunter Region, the northern slopes region and northwestern NSW.

Fire danger ratings are very high along the NSW coast as well as in the southern and central ranges.

"Windy and generally dry conditions will result in elevated fire dangers across parts of NSW (on Wednesday)," the Bureau of Meteorology said. The State Government has again forecast "poor" air quality for parts of Sydney, with thick smoke settling in the city basin.

Lingering smoke could be "unhealthy for sensitive people and could cause symptoms, especially in people with heart or lung disease", the state's environment department said.

Air quality was "hazardous" in Sydney's east and southwest on Tuesday but "good" in the northwest.

The smoke is coming from large bushfires in the Blue Mountains and others near Warragamba Dam and in the Hawkesbury area.

There were 111 fires burning across NSW on Tuesday evening, with 54 of these uncontained.

The Currowan blaze near Batemans Bay has so far destroyed at least one home near Kioloa.

The fire reached coastal areas on Tuesday evening.

Damage assessment teams investigating the impact of the Currowan fire have so far been hampered by ongoing dangerous conditions.

"The fire has reached the coast in some areas," the NSW Rural Fire Service said on Tuesday evening. "Firefighters and aircraft are working to protect homes where possible."

title: Canadian team to help fight Aust bushfires
body:
A crack group of Canadian firefighters have answered Australia's call for help to fight devastating bushfires.

Australian officials submitted an official request to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, based in Winnipeg, on Friday and on the weekend, dozens of experienced firefighters from provinces across Canada volunteered to give up Christmas with their families and fly to Australia.

A group of 21 firefighters were selected from the applicants and will gather in Vancouver on Tuesday before flying to Sydney for what is expected to be a 38-day deployment.

"We are pleased to help the people of Australia as they face these devastating fires, especially since Manitoba has been on the receiving end of help from friends and neighbours when wildfires and other natural disasters hit our province," premier of the Canadian province of Manitoba, Brian Pallister, said.

Manitoba is sending two firefighters with British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Ontario and Parks Canada contributing 19 others.

Strong bonds between Manitoba and Australia were built in the most unfortunate circumstances in July and August.

Canadian teenagers Kam McLeod and Bryer Schmegelsky shot dead Australian tourist Lucas Fowler and his girlfriend Chynna Deese on the side of a British Columbia highway and then fled to Manitoba, sparking a massive manhunt involving the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Canadian military.

"There's nothing more Manitoban than offering a helping hand when someone else is in need," Mr Pallister said.

As Australia burns, Canada is heading into winter where temperatures will drop below 20 degrees Celsius.

The assigned firefighters were selected for their unique skill sets.

The Canadians will assist with a variety of roles within the incident management team, including planning, aviation and operations.

title: Air in parts of Sydney as bad as smoking 34 cigarettes
body:
Bushfires surrounding Sydney will again pollute parts of the city today, following on from another day of "poor" air quality yesterday.

The most highly polluted areas of Sydney, in the southwest, registered 680 PM2.5. yesterday, according to NSW Department of Environment data.

According to an app that compares pollution with smoking, that reading was the equivalent of 34 cigarettes if someone breathed in the air all day.

The Daily Telegraph has crunched the numbers for other parts of the state - showing that breathing air outside all day in the city's east yesterday was similar to smoking 19 cigarettes, while Port Macquarie hit 17 ciggies a day and Lismore 20.

Today, firefighters are facing tough conditions while they battle fires around the state.

Warm, dry and windy weather is forecast for the state today, with total fire bans in place for the greater Hunter Region, the northern slopes region and northwestern NSW.

Fire danger ratings are very high along the NSW coast as well as in the southern and central ranges.

"Windy and generally dry conditions will result in elevated fire dangers across parts of NSW (on Wednesday)," the Bureau of Meteorology said. The State Government has again forecast "poor" air quality for parts of Sydney, with thick smoke settling in the city basin.

Lingering smoke could be "unhealthy for sensitive people and could cause symptoms, especially in people with heart or lung disease", the state's environment department said.

Air quality was "hazardous" in Sydney's east and southwest on Tuesday but "good" in the northwest.

The smoke is coming from large bushfires in the Blue Mountains and others near Warragamba Dam and in the Hawkesbury area.

There were 111 fires burning across NSW on Tuesday evening, with 54 of these uncontained.

The Currowan blaze near Batemans Bay has so far destroyed at least one home near Kioloa.

The fire reached coastal areas on Tuesday evening.

Damage assessment teams investigating the impact of the Currowan fire have so far been hampered by ongoing dangerous conditions.

"The fire has reached the coast in some areas," the NSW Rural Fire Service said on Tuesday evening. "Firefighters and aircraft are working to protect homes where possible."

The Currowan fire has burnt through more than 30,000 hectares. A second emergency alert was issued on Tuesday night for a bushfire burning near the northwestern outskirts of Sydney.

The 1800-hectare Three Mile fire is near the town of Wisemans Ferry and is close to the eastern boundary of the 220,000-hectare Gospers Mountain blaze. The emergency warning was downgraded to a watch-and-act alert later on Tuesday night.

title: Bushfire conditions to worsen with hot, windy weather
body: As more than 100 bush and grass fires burn across New South Wales, police are investigating whether a blaze that threatened homes in Western Sydney was deliberately lit. Residents in Cranebrook were told to leave on Tuesday afternoon when fires crept within 50 metres of their homes. Bushfires continue to burn in the Hawksbury area and at Currowan near Batemans Bay - where at least three homes have been destroyed. A very high fire danger rating remains in place for the majority of NSW and up to the Queensland border on Wednesday. Firefighters warned conditions could further deteriorate with warmer weather paired with a wind change on Wednesday afternoon. Image: Getty

title: Energy market operator warns 1.3 million households could lose power this summer
body:
Related Story: Energy operator moves to prevent blackouts in Victoria and SA heatwave

Extreme weather forecast for summer will reduce the reliability of power supply across Australia in the coming months, with ageing coal plants becoming less reliable, the energy market operator has warned.

In August, Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO) said a worst-case scenario could see up to 1.3 million Victorian households without power on extreme weather days if supply was not improved and major generators were not repaired.

That risk remains.

But the operator said a boom in rooftop and grid-scale solar generation in the past year had created the bulk of an extra 3,700 megawatts of generation in the national energy market.

The AEMO summer-readiness plan showed that Victoria remained the state at the highest risk of power outages due to faults at a coal plant in the Latrobe Valley and a gas plant in the west of the state.

The operator also warned that increased dust storms from the drought in New South Wales and Queensland was a risk to solar panels.

In Victoria's east, a coal unit at Loy Yang in Gippsland is still not fixed, but AGL said it would be back online by mid-December.

Meanwhile, a gas plant in the west of the state is not due to be operational until the end of the year.

In an effort to reduce risk, AEMO and Victoria have secured 125 megawatts of extra reserves.

As part of this backup power plan, big energy users, including recycling company Visy, agree to reduce usage on extreme temperature days.

Other states also run the risk of unplanned blackouts because of the increased heatwaves and bushfires.

"In any region, the actual occurrence of load shedding [planned power outage] could be higher than forecast ... given particular combinations of weather events, plant outages, or bushfires,'' the report said.

When supplies are stretched, AEMO may direct power networks to cut power to customers, which is called load shedding.

Networks may also have to shut down areas if the infrastructure cannot handle the demand from homes and businesses.

The industry said it was working hard to meet demand.

"Losing power, even for short periods during a heatwave, can cause real inconvenience," Australian Energy Council chief executive Sarah McNamara said.

"But electricity providers will continue to do everything possible to avoid that occurring.

"We are working with AEMO to have sufficient supply available for the hotter periods."

The spread of rooftop solar, the report said, had boosted capacity and meant that the peak for demand on hot days was occurring later in the day once the sun sets.

Drought could also limit the effectiveness of hydro-electricity generation.

The summer-readiness plan has also highlighted how ageing coal plants continue to be less reliable especially during extreme weather and drier conditions.

"These risks add to the deteriorating reliability of some of the older coal generation plants," AEMO's chief executive officer Audrey Zibelman said.

"Whilst unexpected events can and do happen, particularly when the power system is under significant pressure and most prone to failure, AEMO has worked diligently to prepare the power system appropriately, including the procurement of emergency resources."

Improvements to transmission also remain key, with the current network restricting the distribution of some new energy generation.

The market operator has also secured secondary backup supplies through short and medium term agreements with business to power down -- but they are only paid if they do reduce use.

title: NSW bushfire danger rises as air quality plummets again
body:
Firefighters are facing tough conditions while bushfires surrounding Sydney will again pollute air quality in parts of the city on Wednesday.

Find the latest on bushfires burning across NSW, weather conditions and air quality right here.

There were some 111 fires burning across NSW on Tuesday evening, with 54 of these uncontained.

Residents on NSW's central and south coasts were told on Tuesday night to flee their homes as westerly winds pushed bushfires towards the isolated towns.

The Currowan blaze near Batemans Bay has so far destroyed at least one home near Kioloa.

The fire reached coastal areas on Tuesday evening.

Damage assessment teams investigating the impact of the Currowan fire have so far been hampered by ongoing dangerous conditions.

"The fire has reached the coast in some areas," The NSW Rural Fire Service said on Tuesday evening.

"Firefighters and aircraft are working to protect homes where possible."

The Currowan fire has burnt through more than 30,000 hectares.

A second emergency alert was issued on Tuesday night for a bushfire burning near the northwestern outskirts of Sydney.

The 1800-hectare Three Mile fire is near the town of Wisemans Ferry and is close to the eastern boundary of the 220,000-hectare Gospers Mountain blaze.

It prompted emergency services' texts to residents advising them to evacuate.

The emergency warning was downgraded to a watch and act alert later on Tuesday night.

Warm, dry and windy weather is forecast for the state on Wednesday, with total fire bans in place for the greater Hunter region, the northern slopes region and northwestern NSW.

Fire danger ratings are very high along the NSW coast as well as in the southern and central ranges.

"Windy and generally dry conditions will result in elevated fire dangers across parts of NSW (on Wednesday)," the Bureau of Meteorology said.

The state government has again forecast "poor" air quality for parts of Sydney, with thick smoke settling in the city basin.

Lingering smoke could be "unhealthy for sensitive people, and could cause symptoms, especially in people with heart or lung disease", the state's environment department said.

Air quality was "hazardous" in Sydney's east and southwest on Tuesday but "good" in the northwest.

Sydney's air quality was so bad on Tuesday it was almost the equivalent of smoking a pack- and-a-half of cigarettes.

NSW Department of Environment data showed the highest polluted areas of Sydney, in the southwest, registered 680 PM2.5.

The city's normal air pollution reading is between five and eight PM2.5 -- a measure of fine particles less than 2.5 microns, or millionths of a metre, in diameter.

The reading was the equivalent of 34 cigarettes if someone breathed in the air all day.

In the east, the pollution was similar to smoking 19 cigarettes, while Port Macquarie had a 17-cigarette day and Lismore hit 20.

The smoke is coming from large bushfires in the Blue Mountains and others near Warragamba Dam, and in the Hawkesbury area.

body:
Sydney's air quality has plunged to dangerously low levels - as several bushfires burn west of the city.

In Camden, the air quality rating was three times the hazardous level - delivering a reading worse than Beijing.

Authorities fear our water supplies could also be contaminated from the smoke - with bushfire ash potentially encouraging algae to bloom at Warragamba Dam.

title: 'I worry about every one of them': the volunteers who rescue injured wildlife
body:
It encapsulated the horror engulfing New South Wales: the footage of a koala mewing in pain as its habitat burned around it. The rescue of that animal, saved from the Long Flat blaze by a woman using her shirt as a shield, went viral.

But the bushfires have injured and displaced vast numbers of other creatures, many of which no longer have homes. Who rescues them - and what does that involve?

Kristie Newton works as campaign manager for the NSW Wildlife Information, Rescue and Education Service (Wires), an organisation that, in normal times, says it cares for tens of thousands of hurt or distressed animals each year.

But these are not normal times.

"We are completely inundated at the moment," she says. "This is the biggest event we have ever dealt with."

Australia's flora and fauna have evolved to coexist with fire - but not with fires of such intensity. Wires' search and rescue teams still can't access many affected areas, even as people in towns or outer suburbs report injured animals fleeing into backyards or roads.

"We probably won't know what we're looking at for about a month or so, maybe longer, until we can really go in and start to get more animals out. But we've lost a lot of habitat, so it's not only directly affecting the animals now, but will continue to affect them for years to come."

It's a sentiment echoed by Vickii Lett, a veteran carer with Clarence Valley Wires.

She's dedicated her property in Lightning Creek near Grafton to caring for wild creatures, so much so that she takes an instant to recall just how many she's currently sheltering.

"I've got three flying foxes, one koala, three - no, four! - redneck wallabies (one of which is burned), and one wallaroo. Oh, and a boobook owl."

A volunteer since 1988, Lett has never experienced fires of such ferocity, affecting such a vast area.

"This is man-made; we've done it," she says.

At the same time, she worries that the immediate crisis might cloak the broader wildlife emergency, the everyday devastation of deforestation and land clearing.

"When you're a wildlife carer, fairly early you realise that you might be able to fix animals, but you've got to have somewhere to put them. They're not pets, but when I release them, I worry about every one of them. They've got to have a home and a food supply."

Wires offers a short rescue and immediate care course that equips people to work with common species.

Volunteers can nominate their level of commitment. They can decide to be carers or rescuers or both - or help with various administrative tasks.

Some take on additional training to specialise in particular animals - anything from koalas to venomous snakes.

That's how Kristina-Lee Willis, a 29-year-old from Corindi Beach (two hours north of Port Macquarie), ended up with Teddy, the baby sugar glider.

Originally, Willis wanted to rescue bats - "to break down the knee-jerk reaction that 'ewww they're disgusting'," - but the first course available focused on possums and gliders.

Then, during the recent blaze, a crew clearing firebreaks on an isolated road near Glenreagh found a glider joey on the ground.

"It was so sweet: this big burly bloke who was driving the dozer carried her crooked up in his arm all the way back to their base. A lady made the call to Wires and then another two gentlemen drove her to the Golden Dog pub in the middle of Glenreagh. And I took her from there."

A little glider means a lot of work.

Teddy - named after the dozer driver who cuddled her - only drinks a special milk formula.

"She's very clever," says Willis, with maternal pride. "She doesn't need a bottle. She laps at milk from the tiny little spoon or from the bottle cap."

But that's just the beginning.

"Now she's older, she's getting little bugs like crickets and meal worms and some moths when I can catch them, though that's really tricky. And also some sap. She likes to chew on some branches and lick at blossoms as well."

Teddy's gaining weight and will, with luck, make a full recovery.

But she's just one animal - and so very, very many need help. At the Port Macquarie Koala Hospital, the volunteers feel that strain.

The facility boasts 14 intensive care units and can house up to 50 animals.

Hospital president Sue Ashton worked in the corporate world before retiring to Port Macquarie two years ago, and then taking up a vacancy on the hospital board. "I enjoyed my old job. But this is so satisfying - working with wild animals and seeing them rehabilitated back into the wild."

Yet after the recent fires, she fears for the long-term future of the species.

In places like the Lake Innes nature reserve, as many as two-thirds of wild koalas seem to have died, incinerated by the astonishing heat. Those that survived were dehydrated; many had been burned on their paws, noses and mouths.

"We've got to cut the dead skin off, bathe their wounds, then treat them with a cream for burns and bandage them," Ashton says. "We're giving them a low lactose milk supplement, for extra nutrients and hydration - some of them aren't eating leaves because their mouth is burnt. The really bad ones have gone into home care. Some might need to be fed more frequently; they need to have their noses rubbed with cream or something like that."

Many of the centre's 150 volunteers currently come in almost daily, and their physical exhaustion exacerbates the toll of watching animals suffer.

Burns are, after all, notoriously difficult to heal. Several of the injured koalas, including the one rescued at Long Flat, have had to be euthanised.

Nicole Blums, from Brisbane's Rescue Collective, knows how shattering wildlife volunteering can be.

She established her group specifically to help resource frontline carers, providing them with basic materials as well as little gifts to lift their spirits.

"Over the last nine days," she says, "Wires has received nine carloads and trailer loads of resources from us. That includes medical supplies, drugs for the animals, formulas, feeding bottles, joey pouches, bat wraps: anything that they need to be able to spend more time with the animals."

A fortnight ago, her group consisted of four women; now it's grown to about 20.

Like the other volunteers, she's been appalled by the fires; like them, she's been buoyed by the community response.

"Working in rescue, you see a lot of bad things and you can begin to hate the human race," Blums says. "But every time we start to think it's too much, it's too heavy for our hearts, we open a box and we find a letter from one of our supporters or a drawing from one of the kids." Her voice catches slightly. "That gives us strength to know that we are making a difference and that we have so much behind us now that we can't stop."

The rescue organisations need donations. They also need volunteers. But Wires' Kristie Newton stresses that it's possible for anyone to help native animals, just by taking very simple steps.

"If people are in an area that's affected by fire or even by heat, if they can leave bowls of water for birds and animals, that's fantastic."

Likewise, a cardboard box and towel kept in your car can help contain an injured animal, if it's possible to do so safely.

"If you do encounter any injured animals," she says, "call your local wildlife group - and get them help as soon as possible. It really can save lives."

title: Fatal Car Crash Sparks Bushfire in Hunter Region of New South Wales
body: A fatal car crash sparked a bushfire in the Hunter region of New South Wales, Australia, on Wednesday, December 3, local media reported. The fire was burning more than 200 hectares (about 500 acres) near Pelaw Main in the Hunter region at the time of writing, according to an update from the NSW Rural Fire Service (NSW RFS). The fire was initially under the highest emergency warning and then downgraded to the mid-range Watch and Act level. The blaze was most recently downgraded to the lowest warning level due to cooler temperatures and decreasing wind speeds, the NSW RFS said. The fire was moving in a southeastern direction toward Richmond Vale, and firefighters were working to protect nearby homes, according to the NSW RFS. Homes on Richmond Vale Road were evacuated, while some other residents were urged to seek shelter as it was "too late" for them to leave, local media reported. This video shows a large air tanker dropping fire retardant on the blaze as smoke fills the sky. The NSW RFS said there were currently 111 fires burning in the region, 51 of which were not yet contained. The Pelaw Main fire started when a vehicle drove off the road, hit a pole, and ignited, reports said. The driver was pronounced dead at the scene. Credit: NSW Rural Fire Service via Storyful

title: Australian man rescued after stranded in outback for 13 nights, friend still missing
body:
A second person among a trio of friends who have been missing the Australian outback for nearly two weeks was rescued Tuesday, as the search continues for the remaining person.

The Northern Territory Police said Phu Tran was found by a livestock farmer in a remote area south of Alice Springs and was taken to a hospital to be treated for exposure.

Police Superintendent Pauline Vicary said at a news conference that the 40-year-old survived after finding some groundwater.

"If you believe in miracles, I'm saying it's a miracle," she said Tuesday.

AUSTRALIAN WOMAN SURVIVES BEING STRANDED FOR NEARLY 2 WEEKS IN OUTBACK

The trio set out from Alice Springs for an afternoon drive on Nov. 19 when their car got stuck in a riverbed in the arid region, according to police. On Sunday, officials announced they found 52-year-old Tamra McBeath-Riley near a waterhole where the group had been staying.

McBeath-Riley said during a Monday news conference that on Thursday her friends -- Claire Hockridge, 46, and Tran -- began the 12-mile journey to reach a nearby highway, planning to avoid the desert heat -- which came close to 104 Fahrenheit in recent days -- by walking at night and carrying whatever water they could find.

"We tried many times to try to get out, but just couldn't get out, so ventured forth to try and find some shelter and some water," she said. "The river was just too large, we couldn't get out."

During the day, the group dug a hole underneath the car to stay cool and then slept in the vehicle at night, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation reported. During that time period, the trio survived on six liters of water, 10 cans of iced vodka, a packet of biscuits and some beef noodles.

McBeath-Riley said she decided to stay at the waterhole with her Staffordshire terrier because she did not think the dog would survive a walk to the Stuart Highway, which connects Australia's north and south coasts. The group did not know if anyone was looking for them.

AUSTRALIAN FIREFIGHTER ACCUSED OF ARSON AMID BUSHFIRE CRISIS, POLICE SAY

Vicary told Australia's NT News that Tran and Hockridge separated after finding the fence on the farm property, and the 40-year-old decided to follow the fence line for two days until he was discovered by the farmer and given water.

She added that Tran was "slightly disoriented" when he was found but in good spirits.

CLICK HERE FOR THE FOX NEWS APP

Police said Monday that rescue efforts have "ramped up," with two helicopters covering 14 square miles from the Stuart Highway, the general area where it is believed Hockridge may be. Vicary said that so far searchers had only found one set of footprints.

"It's quite a diverse terrain," she told reporters. "There's sandy dunes, there's hard clay, there's areas of dense trees, but there are also rocks and ranges in the area."

title: Residents warned over East Coast fire
body:
A WATCH and act alert has been issued for an East Coast town with residents warned they may be at high risk.

The Tasmania Fire Service said a bushfire burning at Mcneills Rd, Swansea, would be difficult to control.

Residents of Mcneills Rd have been warned to expect smoke from the fire as well as falling embers and ash.

Two light rotary wing aircraft, one light tanker and one personnel carrier are at the scene of the fire.

The TFS said residents should take action now to protect their homes but if you are not prepared for a bushfire, be ready to leave for a safer place. If your family has a bushfire survival plan, use it now.

People who don't live near Mcneills Road are asked to stay away.

A smoke alert has also been issued for a fire burning near Exeter, Gravelly Beach and Blackwall on the western side of the Tamar River.

The TFS said there was no threat to communities from the fire but there may be smoke and ash visible around the area.

Discarded tyres within the burnt area will mean smoke from the fire will reduce air quality and can be a health risk, especially for vulnerable people such as the elderly and those with chronic medical conditions.

People in smoke affected areas should:

Stay indoors with windows and doors closed where possible.

Follow your asthma action plan, or your plan for managing flare-ups of other health conditions.

Switch air conditioners to 'recycle' or 'recirculate'.

Consider visiting a friend's place, the library, shopping centre or sports centre if your home gets too hot for comfort or a lot of smoke gets in.

Avoid physical activity outdoors.

Get immediate medical advice or care if your symptoms get worse, .

For more tips visit www.dhhs.tas.gov.au

Keep updated on the fires by listening to ABC Local Radio or look at the TFS website at www.fire.tas.gov.au.

title: Backup power ready as grid braces for heat
body:
Backup power ready as grid braces for heatRebecca GredleyAAP Tuesday, 3 December 2019 9:06PM

Extreme temperatures will put coal-fired power plants under stress this summer, with backup electricity sources ready to prevent Australians experiencing blackouts.

The Australian Energy Market Operator has on Wednesday released its summer readiness plan as the system braces for high temperatures and possible outages caused by bushfires.

Most of the backup power has been sourced for Victoria and South Australia, with the rest in New South Wales and Queensland.

AEMO chief executive Audrey Zibelman said unexpected events can and do happen, so it's pivotal emergency resources are ready.

"The Bureau of Meteorology is forecasting both warmer than average and extreme temperatures this summer, and an ongoing and significant risk of bushfires with drier than usual conditions," she said.

"These risks add to the deteriorating reliability of some of the older coal generation plants."

Rooftop and grid-scale solar power have made up the majority of new generation in the National Electricity Market since last summer, AEMO says.

"The introduction of these resources delivers a welcomed improvement to reliability and reduces the need to procure further out of market reserves," Ms Zibelman said.

Most of the backup power sources will only be paid for if they're needed, she added.

AEMO doesn't expect drought conditions to make much of a dent in power supply.

title: 'Cracks' in Victoria's emergency system expected to be laid bare within weeks
body:
Our coverage of the bushfire crisis is free for all readers. Please consider supporting our journalism with a subscription.

The "cracks" in Victoria's emergency management system is expected to be laid bare within weeks as authorities scramble ahead of a scorching summer to ensure the state's aerial firefighting fleet can cope with an early start to this year's challenging fire season.

Victoria has "very few options" to call upon additional firebombing aircraft, putting at risk lives, properties and lands, according to a senior source familiar with the state's fire fighting plan.

"At some point, if things get really busy, if those aircrafts are allocated to fires, you've only got to look at what's available and there's not enough available," said the source, who spoke on the condition of anonymity for fear of losing their job.

"We are far from prepared and the challenging season will show the cracks in the system."

title: The Life of Brian: Dumped bank CEO's mixed legacy
body:
Also, any credible assessment of his legacy will require the final publication of Promontory's review of accountability for the AUSTRAC mess as well as the outcome of reviews and investigations by the prudential and securities regulators.

It is almost certain other executives will have to share responsibility for the failure in the bank's controls, operational procedures and reporting system for anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing.

Nevertheless, it is possible, even at this time of heightened emotional responses to the AUSTRAC disaster, to compile a scorecard of how Hartzer performed against the financial and operational measures.

Hartzer's tenure as CEO began on February 2, 2015. He inherited deep-seated technology problems from Gail Kelly. She inherited the same from David Morgan. Lack of investment in systems over 20 years left the bank vulnerable to technology disruption and poorly prepared to respond to changing consumer behaviour.

The acquisition of St George Bank brought into the Westpac fold a superior banking platform but neither Kelly or Hartzer were able to make the financial commitment to put the entire bank on one platform.

Hartzer spent a lot of time putting out bushfires that were left smouldering by his predecessors.

Hartzer spent years stabilising Westpac's systems which were notorious for outages. He only really fixed this in 2018. His tangible achievement in IT is the creation of the customer service hub which puts all of each customer's product relationships in one place.

He deserves praise for the appointment of two world leading chief information officers: Dave Curran and Craig Bright. But he leaves behind a spaghetti of legacy systems that must be fixed at some stage to bring Westpac up to scratch with the industry leader, Commonwealth Bank of Australia.

The shining IT legacy of Hartzer's tenure was the Panorama wealth platform. It gives Westpac a strong position in retirement incomes but it cost twice what was expected and took several years longer than expected to be fully operational.

Hartzer preserved Westpac's iron-clad commitment to credit quality. This cultural trait was seared into the bank's soul in the "near death" experience in 1991-92. But having industry leading credit quality is not much good if your loan book is flat or going backwards.

Executive changes Hartzer made in consumer banking and business banking failed to deliver industry leading results. Progress in Hartzer's goal of a "customer revolution" was extremely slow. The bank's net promoter score in consumer retail was negative when the world's best banks have NPS scores of 50 or higher.

Hartzer spent a lot of time putting out bushfires that were left smouldering by his predecessors. The bank's wealth management division was built on the crooked foundations of commission driven sales.

By the time Hartzer came to fix this problem it was a key focus of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission and the Hayne royal commission. The bank severely underestimated the cost of remediation which ballooned to about 10 times the original estimate.

Hartzer performed well in front of Kenneth Hayne and always put in a consummate performance in front of the parliamentary committees. Mind you, the woeful talent of some of the MPs helped make Hartzer look especially good at times.

His tenure coincided with a crackdown on capital by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority. He had to oversee two capital raisings to ensure Westpac was unquestionably strong. Unfortunately for shareholders the AUSTRAC matter could stretch the bank's capital.

Hartzer and the outgoing chairman, Lindsay Maxsted, get poor marks for succession planning. The bench strength on the executive committee is weak relative to other banks and it is not immediately obvious that the successor for Maxsted is already in the boardroom.

For many Westpac investors, the ultimate measure of performance is the total shareholder return. Over Hartzer's time as CEO the stock returned 8.7 per cent compared to 59 per cent for the S&P ASX200.

The three other big banks beat Westpac's performance by a wide margin, with the exception of ANZ Banking Group which was up 12 per cent. CBA was up 31 per cent and National Australia Bank up 20 per cent.

title: NSW bushfires threatening properties as hot, windy conditions stoke flames
body:
Related Story: Firefighters battle to defend beach properties near Batemans Bay

More than 100 fires are burning across NSW tonight due to warm and windy conditions, and an emergency situation continues at the Currowan fire on the South Coast.

That blaze is burning between Batemans Bay and Ulladulla and spreading quickly towards Kioloa, Pretty Beach, Pebbly Beach, Depot Beach and Durras North.

Residents in those areas have been told it is too late to leave and firefighters are working to protect homes.

The fire is also moving east and those in Termeil and Flat Rock have also been urged to take shelter.

A tweet from the NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) shows the intense, smoky conditions firefighters are battling, including hugely limited visibility.

The bushfire, which has burnt almost 30,000 hectares, has closed the Princes Highway between Burrill Lake and the Kings Highway turnoff.

Evacuation centres have been set up for the surrounding areas at the Ulladulla Civic Centre and the Mackay Park Function Centre at Batemans Bay.

A fire in the Yengo and Dharug national parks was also burning at emergency level earlier but has since been downgraded.

Those in the surrounding areas of Mangrove Creek, Greengrove and Lower Mangrove should still enact their bushfire survival plan.

Earlier, residents around Pelaw Main, east of Cessnock, came under threat from a bushfire caused by a single-vehicle car crash on Leggetts Drive.

However the threat to properties has also now been downgraded.

Fires burning near Cranebrook, north of Penrith, were also encroaching on properties earlier but an emergency warning has similarly been downgraded to watch and act.

Residents in the area of Smeeton Road, Londonderry and Cranebrook are now being told to monitor conditions.

Ben Shepherd from the RFS said fires across the state had flared up this afternoon as it became hotter and the wind picked up.

"It is going to be an interesting 48 hours as we start to see some of the fires really spread through the landscape," he said.

title: Fire emergency in Perth's south as city swelters through 40 degree day
body:
Perth sweltered through a 40-degree scorcher on Tuesday, the earliest in December the city has cracked the 40 mark since records began.

More than 100 firefighters are battling a bushfire in Forrestdale, where residents have been ordered to leave, warned their lives are at risk.

Watch the video above

The blaze started near the intersection of Nicholson Road and Rowley Road in Oakford around 3.30 pm.

Aerial support flew in, quickly backed up by firefighters on the ground.

The heat and dry conditions made battling the fire difficult.

An emergency fire warning is in place, with Armadale Arena opened up as an evacuation centre.

The warning has been issued for people in an area bounded by Armadale Road, Tonkin Highway, Oxley Road, Commercial Road and Weld Street.

The fire is moving in a northeasterly direction and is described as being out of control and unpredictable.

Gooseberry Hill hit 41.8 and Pearce reached a maximum of 42.2.

The forecast for the rest of the week isn't much cooler.

Wednesday is predicted to reach 36, Thursday 38, and Friday a whopping 41, with temperatures expected to cool down on the weekend.

title: Communities told to seek shelter as fire escalates
body:
Strong westerly winds have whipped up the remote Three Mile bushfire and pushed it in the direction of remote Central Coast communities.

NSW Rural Fire Service Inspector Ben Shepherd said there had been a quick escalation of the fire in the Hawkesbury River LGA and there were now spot fires in the Mangrove Creek and Lower Mangrove Areas.

Emergency text messages have been sent out to communities to warn them of the approaching fire.

"This moves the fire into the very western area of the Central Coast," Inspector Shepherd said.

"There are a number of properties in and around the Mangrove Creek area and the fire has been escalated to an emergency warning."

"If you are in the area of Mangrove Creek, Greengrove and Lower Mangrove, shelter as the fire approaches. Protect yourself from the heat of the fire."

title: Bushfire threatens lives and homes south of Perth as city swelters
body:
Our coverage of the bushfire crisis is free for all readers. Please consider supporting our journalism with a subscription.

Residents of Oakford and Forrestdale south of Perth are being urged to leave their properties after a bushfire watch and act alert was triggered for the area just after 4pm.

The fire started near the intersection of Nicholson Road and Rowley Road in Oakford and by 4.15pm was moving out of control in a north easterly direction.

Department of Fire and Emergency Services warned there was a possible threat to lives and homes.

The watch and act has been issued for people in an area bounded by Nicholson Road, Rowley Road, Tonkin Highway and Armadale Road in parts of Forrestdale and northern parts of Oakford.

The department warned residents to leave now if the way was clear as well as close all doors and windows and turn off evaporative air conditioners, but keep water running through the system if possible.

title: Bushfire threat in Forrestdale and Oakford
body:
Bushfire alert issued for parts of Forrestdale and OakfordThe West Australian Tuesday, 3 December 2019 4:14PM

A bushfire watch and act has been issued for parts of Forrestdale and Oakford this afternoon, with a possible threat to lives and homes.

The alert has been issued for people in the area bounded by Nicholson Road, Rowley Road, Tonkin Highway and Armadale Road in the City of Armadale and Shire of Serpentine-Jarrahdale.

The fire started near the intersection of Nicholson Road and Rowley Road in Oakford.

It is moving in a north easterly direction and is out of control and unpredictable.

WHAT TO DOIf you are not prepared or you plan to leave, leave now if the way is clear.Close all doors and windows and turn off evaporative air conditioners, but keep water running through the system if possible.If you are well prepared and plan to actively defend your home, make final preparations now.If you plan to stay and actively defend, do not rely on mains water pressure as it may be affected. You need to have access to an independent water supply, and start patrolling your property to put out spot fires.If you are not at home, do not try to return as conditions in the area could be very dangerous.Get the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.

Sign up for our emails

title: Two emergency warnings for NSW fires
body:
Sydney was ringed by bushfires on Tuesday afternoon causing heavy smoke to settle in the city's basin.

A total of 116 bush and grass fires are burning across NSW with 56 uncontained and more than 2000 firefighters in the field being supported by aircraft.

An emergency warning was issued on Tuesday afternoon for a small bushfire in Cranebrook in western Sydney.

"The fire is burning in an easterly direction," the Rural Fire Service said before 4pm.

"Properties in the area around Smeeton Road are at risk. Firefighters and aircraft are working to slow the fire and protect homes."

Firefighters on the South Coast have also been working to save homes with a fresh emergency warning issued on Tuesday afternoon for an out-of-control fire at Currowan burning between Batemans Bay and Ulladulla.

The 29,000-hectare bushfire is being pushed east and northeast towards the coastal communities of Termeil, Bawley Point and Pebbly Beach.

The RFS warned residents in the Termeil and Flat Rock area that it was too late to leave.

"Seek shelter as the fire approaches. Protect yourself from the heat of the fire," the agency said in a statement.

RFS commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons earlier on Tuesday confirmed properties west of Kioloa had been damaged and destroyed. Authorities are assessing the extent of the losses.

Heavy smoke will linger in the Sydney basin for at least three more days with authorities advising those most at risk to stay indoors.

The smoke is coming from large bushfires in the Blue Mountains and also near Warragamba Dam and in the Hawkesbury area.

A so-called temperature inversion - where warm air overlays cooler air in the atmosphere - is trapping the smoke and preventing its dissipation.

Air quality was "hazardous" in Sydney's east and southwest on Tuesday afternoon but "good" in the city's northwest.

There were four watch and act alerts current in NSW on Tuesday afternoon for fires at North Black Range east of Braidwood, Green Wattle Creek southwest of the Warragamba Dam wall, the Yengo National Park west of Cessnock and at Kurri Kurri in the Hunter region.

title: Huge areas of national parks, heritage locations hit by bushfires
body:
Our coverage of the bushfire crisis is free for all readers. Please consider supporting our journalism with a subscription.

More than 10 per cent of the state's national parks have been burned during the fire season, with a large chunk of the Blue Mountains World Heritage Area impacted.

About 800,000 of the two million hectares burnt around the state so far are in national parks. This equates to around 11 per cent of NSW' 7.2 million hectares of national park.

The damage has been mostly due to the Gospers Mountain fire which began in November. That alone has ripped through more than 225,000 hectares of land.

As of Tuesday afternoon, this fire was burning in the Wollemi and Yengo National Parks, and Parr State Recreation areas, and was being controlled.

title: Hazardous air quality for Sydney as new out-of-control blazes burn
body:
Two emergency warnings have been issued for out-of-control bushfires near Batemans Bay on the NSW South Coast and in western Sydney.

A total of 116 bush and grass fires are burning across NSW with 56 uncontained and more than 2000 firefighters in the field being supported by aircraft.

title: Secret report into St Patrick's Day fires reveals power giant's failings
body:
Our coverage of the bushfire crisis is free for all readers. Please consider supporting our journalism with a subscription.

An explosive secret Powercor report reveals the electricity giant knows it has a flawed pole inspection regime for its ageing system and doesn't investigate or report all its pole failures.

The existence of the reliability centred maintenance report dated October 28, 2019, only came to light during cross-examination of Powercor's maintenance chief Matthew Settle during a damages case in the Supreme Court late last week.

One hundred and eighty nine people who were affected by the The Sisters/Garvoc bushfire are taking action for compensation against Powercor and inspection subcontractor Electrix after a rotten, termite-ravaged wooden pole snapped on St Patrick's Day last year sparking the blaze.

Barrister for the victims Francis Tiernan, QC, called for the secret report to be provided during hearings last week and Powercor was given a deadline of 3pm on Friday.

title: Smoke alarm: Open officials increase medical staff as haze descends
body:
Australian Open organisers will bolster the number of medical staff on course but are confident the lingering smoke from the state's bushfires won't present a health hazard when the tournament gets under way on Thursday.

Officials plan to seek further advice about the forecast wind directions after an eerie smog enveloped The Australian Golf Club on Tuesday.

Golf Australia chief executive Stephen Pitt said his first thoughts were with firefighters and those affected by the fires before conceding the air quality level was not an issue administrators have dealt with in the past.

"We've had storms, rain and hail, heat and cold and all those sorts of things are your typical golf tournament issues, but this one is new," Pitt said.

title: Firefighting Helicopter Drops Water on Bushfire in the Blue Mountains
body: Waterbombing aircraft took to the skies to fight the hard-to-access Ruined Castle bushfire in the New South Wales Blue Mountains on Tuesday, December 3. The Rural Fire Service has warned the fire is burning in a northerly direction towards Cliff Drive in Katoomba, threatening to climb the cliff face and affect properties in the town. The difficulty of fighting the fire is demonstrated in this video, which shows a waterbombing helicopter dumping its load on the wall of a valley. The Ruined Castle fire was one of over 50 bushfires burning out of control in New South Wales on December 3. Credit: back2thebush via Storyful

title: Fire threatens homes in Sydney's west
body:
Residents in Tadmore Rd, Cranebrook have been evacuated, as reports the bushfire has overrun a home in the street.

The Penrith Press understands firefighters were battling to save the home around 4pm as police ordered residents out of the street.

Several volunteer crews rushed to reports of the blazes around 3pm this afternoon as the fire, moving in an easterly direction, began to threaten several at-risk homes in the area.

A NSW Rural Fire Service spokesmans told the Penrith Press firefighters and aircraft are working to slow the fire and protect homes.

"If you are in the area of Smeeton Rd, Londonderry and Cranebrook you are at risk," the spokesman said.

"Protect yourself from the heat of the fire. If the fire impacts, seek shelter in a solid structure to protect yourself from the heat of the fire."

Several other out of control fires are also burning at 35 Kenmare Rd and Wingara Glen, Londonderry, while Fire and Recue NSW have contained a bushfire at Hawkesbury Rd, Hawkesbury Heights.

Press reporter, Joel Erickson, said the fire is moving closer to residential properties as wind increases.

"Police have cordoned off Smeeton Rd at Cranebrook Rd, as well as Firetrail and Hinxman roads," Press reporter said. "Firefighters at the Cranebrook blaze are supported by helicopter aerial surveillance."

Llandilo resident, Krity Lee, said she was on her way to pick up her children from The Lakes Christian College in Castlereagh when she saw the fire from Church Lane.

"I saw the smoke from home and didn't realise how close it was to homes in Cranebrook," she said.

"I couldn't believe how close it was, police were blocking off the road -- it was very chaotic."

title: Deadly WA fires prompt resourcing call
body:
A West Australian coroner has handed down a dozen recommendations from an inquest into the deadly bushfires in Esperance in 2015, including making more firefighting resources available.

Farmer Kym Curnow and backpackers Thomas Butcher, Anna Sushchova Winther and Julia Kohrs-Lichte died in Scaddan during lightning-sparked blazes that lasted 11 days.

Coroner Sarah Linton handed down her findings on Tuesday, and her top recommendation was immediately filling three Department of Fire and Emergency Services positions in the area.

She noted blazes in the area in March this year were bigger in area but fortunately not deadly, which demonstrated "large and complex fires of this kind are no longer an isolated event".

title: Share your Christmas spirit
body:
Christmas is all about giving, and this year Quest Community News is sharing how you can make somebody else's festive season a little bit brighter. Whether it's putting up Christmas lights or food on the tables of vulnerable people in your community, every bit of goodwill counts this festive season.

Volunteers at FareShare kitchen at Morningside are rolling up their sleeves to help fill the bellies of some of southeast Queensland's most vulnerable this Christmas.

"FareShare volunteers are making a special Christmas edition lunch for Dig In, one of our charity partners," FareShare's Mary Pope said.

"Dig In serves a free FareShare meal each Saturday at Kemp Place in Fortitude Valley for people in need, and we're pleased to be able to make them a full Christmas delight -- Roast turkey with all the trimmings, roast veg, gravy, baked ham and Xmas pudding with custard. Special Christmas cookies will also be available for guests to take away with them.

"Many of the meals made in our kitchen over the course of December will include Christmas flavours, and these too will be distributed across Queensland to communities in need this season."

FareShare is always looking for volunteers over the age of 16 to help them create nourishing meals from Foodbank Queensland. Visit fareshare.net.au

GIVIT is an online platform aiming to match donations from the public directly to those in need through charities and not-for-profits.

This festive season they are collecting gifts for children living in foster care, aiming for 9500 donated gifts for children from newborn through to 17 years old.

They are also collecting supplies for more than 150 people who lost their homes in bushfires across Australia this year, through financial donations from the general public. Visit givit.org.au

More than 137,000 animals are stuck in RSPCA shelters across the state this festive season. You could adopt a cat, dog, Guinea pig, or even chicken and change their life.

But if you don't have room for a pet then you can always donate animal food, beds, toys, bowls, brushes, nail clips, or jackets.

However, if you prefer to donate time over money, you can volunteer your time and help to take care of the animals at one of their shelters. Visit rspca.qld.org.au

Another way to share the Christmas spirit is through volunteering for community projects. This is a good way to socialise with others as well as creating a place, performances, or product that benefits other people. Check out volunteeringqld.org.au to find an opportunity to contribute to your local community.

While southeast Queensland is dry, much of Queensland is in the grips of drought. The final way you can share Christmas is by helping farming families, either through simple donations to charities like Rural Aid, Drought Angles, or Aussie Helpers. Donations can be financial, food (for farmers or animals), or water. Visit ruralaid.org.au or droughtangels.org.au or aussiehelpers.org.au

So, instead of staying home all Christmas holidays, come down to your local charities (Vinnies, R.S. P. C. A, Fare Share, or Drought Angles) and donate your time, money, clothes, etc. Or build a community garden, even just talk to the less fortunate, and share the Christmas Spirit.

title: Fire ban remains for Redlands  --  here's what to remember
body:
Full Digital Access: $5 per month for the first 3 months (conditions apply)

The local fire ban will remain in place until Tuesday, December 17 and has been issued for the Redland City, Brisbane City and Moreton Bay Regional councils.

It has been kept in place because of heightened fire conditions, which are perfect for bushfires to ignite and quickly spread.

Residents and business should remember the following:

● All open fires are banned

● All permits to light fires issued in the designated areas have been cancelled

● Use power tools with extreme care and have fire extinguishing equipment on hand

More Redlands news:

Fire strike teams prepare to protect Redlands Coast

title: Firefighters Drive Down Highway Surrounded by Flames From Currowan Blaze
body: A fresh emergency warning was issued for the Currowan fire on the New South Wales south coast on Tuesday, December 3 as nearby residents were told to seek shelter from the flames. The NSW Rural Fire Service told people in two regions east of the blaze that it was too late to leave the area and to "protect yourself from the heat of the fire." The out-of-control fire north of Batemans Bay had earlier been downgraded to a 'watch and act' alert after burning through around 25,000 hectares of bushland. This video from Fire and Rescue NSW Station 398 Narooma shows firefighters driving down a highway surrounded by flames on the night of December 2. Sections of the Pacific Highway have been closed due to the blaze. The Currowan fire had destroyed at least one property and several other structures, according to reports. The fire was one of more than 50 uncontained bushfires burning around the state, the NSW Rural Fire Service said. Credit: Fire and Rescue NSW Station 398 Narooma via Storyful

title: Sydney's NYE celebrations for hope, giving and a call for climate action
body: December 4, 2019. Lord Mayor Clover Moore in Sydney alongside Fortunato Foti from Foti Fireworks and NSW Police assistant commissioner Mick Willing, speaks about preparations for Sydney's New Year's celebrations. Ms Moore says Sydney will see in 2020 with its usual fireworks display despite bushfires burning across NSW. "We have known for many years that if we have really serious wind conditions we can't do the fireworks," Ms Moore says. "It is a truly shocking time and we're all hoping that this going to lead to very effective action by our federal government to stop coal mining." (AAP Video/Michael Wade)

title: Firefighters Battle Bushfire Threatening Homes on New South Wales South Coast
body: An emergency-level bushfire was threatening properties on the south coast of New South Wales near Currowan on December 3. The Currowan fire, which has burned through more than 29,000 hectares of bushland, was moving towards the areas of Termeil, Bawley Point, Pebbly Beach, East Lynne and Benandarah. Residents in Termeil and Flat Rock were told to protect themselves from the heat of the fire as it was "too late to leave", while those in Kioloa, Depot Beach, Pebbly Beach and Pretty Beach were told to "monitor conditions" and follow bushfire survival plans. Evacuation centres were set up in nearby communities. This footage shows firefighters battling the blaze near Kioloa on December 2 and 3. Credit: Jess McAlpine via Storyful

title: Too late to leave for South Coast residents as fire spreads to beaches
body:
Our coverage of the bushfire crisis is free for all readers. Please consider supporting our journalism with a subscription.

An out-of-control bushfire on NSW's South Coast has burned through 40,000 hectares of land and is threatening several towns north of Batemans Bay.

The Rural Fire Service has advised residents between Termeil and Flat Rock that it's "too late to leave" and to seek shelter.

Several beachside holiday areas are threatened by the blaze, which continues to move east, and people in Kioloa, Pretty Beach, Pebbly Beach, Depot Beach and Durras North have also been told it's too late to leave, while those further south have been told to leave now for Batemans Bay, where an evacuation centre has been established.

The Princes Highway remains partially closed between Burrill Lake and the Kings Highway turn-off after the fire jumped across the road last night.

title: NSW South Coast fire escalates as firefighters battle to defend beach properties
body:
Related Story: Buildings destroyed before NSW bushfire's advance on beach communities slows

Firefighters have declared an emergency as they struggle to defend property from an out-of-control bushfire north of Batemans Bay on the New South Wales South Coast.

The Currowan fire's alert level escalated this afternoon as strong winds pushed it closer to the Termeil and Flat Rock communities.

Residents in those areas are urged to seek shelter as the blaze approaches and to protect themselves from the heat. It is too late for them to leave.

The bushfire, which has burnt almost 30,000 hectares, has closed the Princes Highway between Batemans Bay and Dolphin Point.

The NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) urges people who remain in the cut-off areas west of the highway, between East Lynne and Termeil, as well as those between Bawley Point and North Durras, to monitor conditions, take the advice of firefighters, and follow their bushfire survival plans.

Residents in South Durras are urged to leave towards Batemans Bay, while residents north of Termeil should head towards Ulladulla, if it's safe to do so.

The fire had been downgraded overnight from emergency to watch and act, but strengthening winds throughout the date increased the threat to coastal communities.

The fire continues to burn in an easterly and north-easterly direction towards Termeil.

Ben Shepherd, from the RFS, said the blaze grew significantly in the past few hours and more properties could be threatened this afternoon.

"We are expecting those conditions to hold through the afternoon as we continue to see these fires flare and run in some very dry landscape," he said.

"So there is the possibility we could see further homes come under threat, even around East Lynne, during the course of the afternoon."

Bawley Point's RFS captain, Charlie Magnuson, said earlier the weather would complicate efforts to save properties.

"We've got these westerlies coming, which are going to push the fire back towards the village, but at this stage we've done a fair bit of containment," he said.

"It's going to be a wait and see how much of that fire will impact either Kioloa or the Bawley Point village.

"There's a lot of potential for this to still come in on us."

More than 100 fires continue to burn across the state, dozens of which are uncontained.

NSW RFS commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons said the threat was likely to worsen rather than ease.

"Unfortunately that's just going to continue to deteriorate as we head into the tail end of this week," he said.

"We are expecting to see much more widespread very high and severe [alerts] right across parts of NSW, including the South Coast, particularly as we head into Thursday and Friday.

"Given the winds and given how dry the landscape is and how volatile the fire behaviour is, any one of these fires could change their alert level."

The Currowan fire destroyed several buildings on Monday, including a house on the Clyde River and several "other structures", the RFS confirmed.

However, no further details were available as firefighters were busy battling the blaze.

title: Sydney smoke to linger three more days
body:
The harbour city has on Tuesday been ringed by large bushfires in the Blue Mountains, near Warragamba Dam and in the Hawkesbury area.

A "temperature inversion" in which warm air overlays cooler air in the atmosphere, meanwhile, has trapped the smoke close to the ground and prevented its dissipation.

Eastern and southwest Sydney were deemed "hazardous" for air quality, as was the Upper Hunter and parts of the Lower Hunter.

Northwest Sydney was deemed of "good" quality.

The lingering smoke has prompted a NSW Health warning for those with heart and lung problems to stay indoors and avoid exercise.

"The best thing you can do is stay indoors, keep your doors and windows shut and if you've got air conditioning, turn that on as well, which helps to clean the air inside," NSW Health's Dr Richard Broome said in a statement.

Face masks are considered ineffective as they fail to filter out smoke particles.

The Bureau of Meteorology's Shuang Wang said the Sydney temperature inversion was likely to persist until at least Friday.

She said westerly winds were blowing smoke right into Sydney.

"It depends if the fires come under control ... a southeasterly change late on Friday (and) conditions would improve," Ms Wang told AAP.

Two million hectares of NSW land have been burnt since July in more than 7000 fires, with authorities dubbing it the "most challenging bushfire season ever".

Six people have died while at least 673 homes have been destroyed.

title: What the bushfire smoke is doing to your heart
body:
If they live in smoke affected areas, Professor Garry Jennings, chief medical advisor of Australia's Heart Foundation, recommends they refrain from outdoor activities.

"Don't allow yourself to get unnecessarily exposed. Give your daily walk or exercise a miss and make it up when the smoke has gone."

While people prone to respiratory conditions are advised to wear masks outdoors, he says people with a history of heart disease may consider doing the same.

Although past studies have produced inconsistent findings, Professor Jennings says there is now an emerging consensus about the increased risk of heart failure, heart attacks, strokes, pulmonary embolism and high blood pressure, during and in a few days after exposure to bushfire smoke.

The evidence shows the denser the smoke, the higher the risk.

Professor Jennings, a cardiologist, says the problem arises from fine particles in the smoke which are smaller than 2.5 micrometres in diameter, a fraction the width of human hair.

These particles have the capacity to travel deep into the lung, into its smallest branches, where they can cross over into the bloodstream.

"Loaded with active ingredients, they can incite inflammation and other problems," says Professor Jennings.

"There is also a suggestion they make the blood a little more coagulable, which may explain the raised risk of stroke and pulmonary embolism."

Others suggest these particles can also affect the autonomic nervous system, which in turn may contribute to instability in blood pressure or increase the heart rate.

Last year, a study published in the Journal of the American Heart Association, looked at over a million emergency room visits across California during 2015 wildfires.

It found a 10 per cent increased risk of presentation with heart attacks, strokes, worsened heart failure symptoms and irregular heart rhythms.

On dense smoke days, emergency department visits for these ailments jumped, particularly among elderly patients.

The study looked at other diseases too, such as appendicitis, and found no increase in hospital presentation.

Professor Jennings says the smoke can accelerate pre-existing cardiovascular conditions. "Nobody gets a heart attack from the last five days. They've set themselves up to have it and the smoke might just bring it forward."

To date, evidence on the cardiovascular impact of bushfire smoke is only available for the short term.

In the meantime, he says having a heart check is better insurance than wearing a mask or staying inside.

title: 'Bring a bit of happiness' to Sydney's sky on New Year's Eve
body:
Our coverage of the bushfire crisis is free for all readers. Please consider supporting our journalism with a subscription.

Lord mayor of Sydney Clover Moore will go ahead with this year's New Year's Eve fireworks in an effort to unite the community, despite some councils and organisations cancelling their celebrations in the wake of the bushfires.

"Cancelling would be of little practical advantage to those who have lost so much in the bush[fires]," she said.

"We are going through really tough times now and it brings us together to celebrate a new year with hope.

"It's a really important time to be together to support each other."
