title: Bushfires cut off South Coast communities as 90km/h wind gusts forecast
body:
Our coverage of the bushfire crisis is free for all readers. Please consider supporting our journalism with a subscription.

A bushfire burning at emergency level on NSW's South Coast has crossed the Princes Highway, cutting off several communities, as almost 130 fires burn across NSW amid very dry and windy conditions on Monday.

The Currowan blaze, which has already burnt more than 11,500 hectares, is burning out-of-control in the Bimberamala and Murramarang national parks, north of Batemans Bay.

With cooler temperatures across most of the state on Monday, firefighters' main concern is strong westerly winds, averaging 40-60km/h with gusts of up to 90km/h in parts.

The Bureau of Meteorology has issued a "severe" warning on Monday morning for damaging winds for people in the Hunter, Illawarra, Northern Tablelands and parts of the Mid North Coast, Central Tablelands and Southern Tablelands.

title: Kids take up clear air fight
body:
BLUE Mountains school pupils are among a swag of volunteers helping to paint a clearer picture of air quality in our region.

Fifteen students at Katoomba Public School have been volunteering their lunchtimes to be part of Blue Mountains and Lithgow Air Watch -- a community-initiated year-long air-quality research project led by the NSW Environment Protection Authority (EPA).

The project, which includes monitoring local smoke haze, is now making publicly available real-time air-quality data from Springwood to Lithgow.

The information will help inform future initiatives to protect local air quality.

An EPA spokeswoman told The Blue Mountains News the project was triggered by interest from the Blue Mountains and Lithgow communities.

Locals were seeking more information on air quality in their local areas, "including the impacts from the transport corridor (Great Western Highway and freight trains)".

The project includes collecting air quality data for 12 months using one temporary compliance air quality monitoring station at Katoomba and 12 low-cost air quality sensors, known as KOALAs, located at Katoomba, Lithgow, Springwood and Wentworth Falls.

Kids at Katoomba Public host and maintain one of these KOALAs, on their school grounds.

KOALAs are solar battery powered and typically communicate air-quality readings at 30 to 40-minute intervals, showing the latest concentration of pollutants in the air.

Teacher Cate Paterson said when the school, which already has a student volunteer environment group, was contacted by the Air Watch Project Steering Committee to be a part of this, "we knew it was a great fit".

"We have a water device on Vale St (which is monitored by our students) that captures the pollution run off from Katoomba St, to stop it from going into the Leura Falls catchment," Ms Paterson said.

Now, once a month, the school's Air Watch volunteers "come with a feather duster and they clean the top of the KOALA, because it's like a solar panel that measures local air quality", she said.

Using a spreadsheet the pupils also record the smoke haze, so scientists from Western Sydney University who are analysing the data from the KOALAs and monitoring station can get a better understanding of the information coming back to them.

"Smoke from hazard reduction burns, bushfires and home wood-burning heaters contains particulate matter which is detected by the compliance monitor and the KOALAs," EPA's spokeswoman said.

Data from the 12 KOALA sensors is available in near real-time at bluemountains.sensors.net.au

Data from Katoomba air quality monitoring station is available on the DPIE website

title: 'Safety is the critical thing' around firefighter recruit training
body: Firefighting is one of the most dangerous jobs in the nation: Sky News has a look into what it takes as a new recruit seeking to be part of the respected profession. 31 new recruits have joined Forest Fire Management Victoria to undertake elite firefighter training. The week-long course gives the trainees the skills they need to prevent and fight bushfires. Forest Fire Management Victoria's Dan White told Sky News, "the critical thing for us is around safety, firefighting is a very dangerous job". Image: News Corp Australia

title: Emergency fires in NSW as winds pick up
body:
Emergency bushfire warnings have been issued for blazes in NSW's Shoalhaven and Upper Hunter regions as the Rural Fire Service prepares for worse to come as summer officially begins.

The so-called Currowan fire burning north of Batemans Bay has already ripped through 7000 hectares and is being fanned by strong westerly winds on Sunday afternoon.

"The fire has crossed the Clyde River," the RFS said in an emergency warning after 3pm.

"If you are in the area to the west of the Princes Highway between Turmeil and East Lynne seek shelter as the fire impacts. It is too late to leave."

Another emergency warning has been issued for a blaze southwest of Merriwa in the Goulburn Rivers National Park.

"There are numerous rural properties in the area which may come under threat," the RFS said on Sunday afternoon of the Meads Creek West fire.

"If you are in the area southwest of Merriwa and you are not prepared, leave now towards Merriwa."

Two million hectares of land have been burnt since July in more than 7000 fires which have raged across the state in the "most challenging bushfire season ever".

Six lives have been lost while 673 homes and 1400 other buildings have been destroyed.

A total fire ban has been issued for Monday across the far north coast, Greater Hunter and New England regions due to forecast hot and windy conditions.

"While it's expected to be cooler tomorrow, it's going to be very windy in many areas," the RFS tweeted.

"This will present challenging conditions for several days with so many fires."

There'll be "very high" fire danger on Monday from the Illawarra and Shoalhaven up through Sydney and along the coast to the Queensland border.

The New England, northern slopes and northwestern fire areas will also face "very high" danger.

There were three watch and act alerts in place on Sunday afternoon along with the two emergency warnings.

The North Black Range blaze west of Braidwood is over 20,000 hectares but is being controlled.

"The fire is burning towards the areas of Jembaicumbene, Bendoura and Majors Creek," the RFS said at 3.30pm.

The other watch and act alerts were near Yerranderie in the southern part of the Blue Mountains.

Firefighters and aircraft were also working on Sunday afternoon to slow a fire burning south of Katoomba.

While it was creating a lot of smoke there was no immediate threat to homes in the Blue Mountains, the RFS advised.

There were some 150 grass and bush fires burning across NSW on Sunday with a third of them uncontained.

title: NSW total fire bans amid almost 150 blazes
body:
Strong winds are hampering NSW firefighters' efforts at a 20,000 hectare blaze in a national park, as the Rural Fire Service prepares for worse to come with summer officially beginning.

Two million hectares of land have been burnt through since July in more than 7000 fires which have raged across the state in the "most challenging bushfire season ever".

Six lives have been lost, while 673 homes and 1400 other buildings have been destroyed, the RFS said.

On Sunday - the first day of summer - the service urged people to ensure they have a plan in place for what are forecast to be hot and dry weeks to come.

"NSW already has faced its most challenging bush fire season ever. Since July, we have seen lives lost, homes destroyed and communities changed forever. And today is the start of summer. How fireproof is your plan?" the RFS tweeted.

The North Black Range blaze burning just east of Canberra in the Tallaganda National Park was upgraded from advice to watch and act about midday on Sunday.

A NSW Rural Fire Service spokesman said firefighters expected things to get worse on Monday as winds increased.

Jembaicumbene, Bendoura and Majors Creek residents were told to leave now towards Araluen if they were unprepared or had planned to leave.

Meanwhile a blaze in the Upper Hunter has also been elevated to watch and act level.

People in the area of the fire, in the Goulburn River National Park to the southwest of Merriwa, are advised to monitor conditions and be ready to take action.

Total fire bans are in place for six fire regions around NSW as firefighters battle nearly 150 blazes statewide amid worsening conditions.

On Sunday about a third of the bush and grass fires were not contained.

A total fire ban is in place for Sunday for the Greater Hunter, which is facing severe fire danger.

The Greater Sydney, Illawarra/Shoalhaven, Central Ranges, Northern Slopes, and northwestern regions are also under a total fire ban.

These regions along with the far South Coast, Southern Ranges and New England, as well as the ACT are under very high fire danger.

Meanwhile, a portable radio repeater providing critical communications for fire crews in northern NSW has been so severely vandalised, it's out of action.

Six tyres, two axles, two jerry cans and radio equipment were stolen from the marked trailer near Nymboida.

"This will potentially endanger fire crews working to protect life and property," Northern Tablelands Team posted online on Saturday.

title: NSW total fire bans amid almost 150 blazes
body:
A 20,000 hectare fire burning just east of Canberra in the Tallaganda National Park has been upgraded to "watch and act".

The NSW Fires Near Me website says fire activity at the North Black Range blaze west of Braidwood had started to pick up around noon on Sunday.

Jembaicumbene, Bendoura and Majors Creek residents were told to leave now towards Araluen.

Total fire bans are in place for six fire regions around NSW as firefighters battle nearly 150 blazes statewide amid worsening conditions.

On Sunday about a third of the 146 bush and grass fires were not contained.

"With Severe fire danger in the Greater Hunter and widespread Very High elsewhere, know what you and your family will do if threatened by fire. Report any unattended fires to 000," the Rural Fire Service posted on Twitter.

A total fire ban is in place for Sunday for the greater Hunter, which is facing "severe" fire danger.

The greater Sydney, Illawarra/Shoalhaven, Central Ranges, Northern Slopes, and northwestern regions are also under a total fire ban.

These regions along with the far South Coast, Southern Ranges and New England, as well as the ACT are under "very high" fire danger.

A "watch and act" alert was issued on Saturday for the 20,770-hectare North Black Range fire burning in the Tallaganda National Park area, but was later downgraded to "advice".

The RFS has warned of worsening conditions over the coming week, with one regional command telling residents that now is the time to talk to family about what to do when a bushfire hits.

"Know what you will do before the fire threatens rather than trying to wing it at the time," the RFS's Northern Tablelands Team posted to Facebook.

Meanwhile, a portable radio repeater providing critical communications for fire crews in northern NSW has been so severely vandalised, it's out of action.

Six tyres, two axles, two jerry cans and radio equipment were stolen from the marked trailer near Nymboida.

"This will potentially endanger fire crews working to protect life and property," Northern Tablelands Team posted online on Saturday.

title: Cool start to summer as smoke haze lingers
body:
Our coverage of the bushfire crisis is free for all readers. Please consider supporting our journalism with a subscription.

It will be a cool start to summer in Sydney with below-average temperatures on Sunday and Monday as a smoke haze lingers over the city.

Temperatures will reach tops of 25 degrees on Sunday and 23 degrees on Monday before warming up to the high 20s and low 30s during the week.

"It's the first day of summer but it's a bit cooler than what we've seen in the past," Abrar Shabren, a forecaster at the Bureau of Meteorology, said.

However, Mr Shabren said it is expected to be a warm summer, with little rainfall expected in the coming weeks.
